Addendum to §1.4 --- ProviderManaged Changes & Adminless Ops

Goal: Let User B (provider) modify an existing booking with zero admin
intervention---reschedule, change price, add/waive fees, issue
refunds---while preserving buyer consent, clear contracts, escrow
accuracy, and an immutable audit trail.

1\) Change Types & Consent Matrix

2\) "Amendment" Object (Single Source of Truth)

Every approved change produces a versioned Amendment attached to the
Booking:

Fields changed (before → after), initiator, timestamp, reason code
(required), 双方 esign if it alters contractual terms (date, price,
deliverables, license).

PDF added to Contracts tab and to both receipts (for taxes and
disputes).

Audit trail (readonly) visible to both parties and Support.

3\) Provider Portal --- "Manage Booking" Actions

Propose New Time (Reschedule)

Date/time picker; optional note; shows buyer availability hints.

Autoapprove rules honored (see §5). Otherwise buyer gets Accept/Decline
card.

Apply Discount / Issue Partial Refund

Enter amount or %; choose reason (goodwill, less time, deliverables
adjusted).

Shows new totals, fee adjustments, and payout impact preview.

No buyer acceptance needed (refunds are onedirectional benefits).

Send Custom Offer Amendment (price ↑ / package swap / license change)

Configure new package/price/deliverables; optional extras.

Buyer receives an Amendment Offer card to Accept/Decline.

Add Extras / Add Overtime

Standard action cards; buyer must accept.

Incremental charge collected; escrow updated; contract addendum
generated.

Adjust Travel (downward) / Waive Fees

Provider can lower/waive automatically calculated travel; cannot
increase without buyer acceptance.

Change Location

Pick new address; system recalculates travel. If cost rises, requires
buyer acceptance; if cost drops, autoapplies and notifies.

Issue Full Refund & Cancel (Providerinitiated cancel)

Applies policy rules; may record a provider strike depending on timing.

Buyer notified immediately; calendar unblocked.

All actions render as Action Cards in the thread and update the Project
Panel in real time.

4\) Money Movement & Fee Logic (Automatic)

Escrow up / down:

Increases (extras, upgrades): capture incremental charge on buyer
acceptance.

Decreases (discounts, partial refunds): reduce escrow instantly and
adjust platform fee prorata.

After payout:

Refunds become postbooking adjustments: provider authorizes a debit (or
we net from next payout). Buyer receives refund net of any
nonrecoverable processing costs per policy.

Platform & processing fees:

Platform fees adjust proportionally to the final job value.

Processing fees follow processor policy; communicate clearly if some
fees are nonrefundable after a window.

Taxes:

Amendment updates taxable base where applicable; amended invoice/receipt
issued to both parties automatically.

5\) Buyer AutoApprove Rules (Optional, SetandForget)

Buyers can preauthorize certain provider changes:

Time shift: autoapprove up to ±30/60/90 min same day.

Date move: autoapprove sameday or within X days window.

Location change: autoapprove within ≤ 5 miles of original.

Price decreases / discounts: always autoapproved.

Travel fee reductions/waivers: autoapproved.

No autoapprove for price increases, deliverable reductions, or license
downgrades.

This lets busy buyers give trusted providers flexibility without
constant taps.

6\) Locks & Fairness Windows

Hard Lock (e.g., \< 24h before start): Provider cannot unilaterally
change time/date; must request or cancel (policy applies).

Soft Lock (24--48h): Provider request requires buyer acceptance; if
declined, original stands or provider may cancel under policy (risking
penalty).

During session: Extensions via Overtime only (both accept).

After session, predelivery: Provider may apply discounts; increasing
price requires buyer approval.

7\) Notifications & Calendar

Buyer receives clear cards: "Provider proposes new time →
Accept/Decline".

On acceptance, update both calendars, send new ICS, refresh Project
Panel timeline.

Decline returns parties to current terms; provider may propose
alternatives or cancel per policy.

8\) Disputes Interplay

Amendments are authoritative in disputes.

If parties disagree on an unaccepted proposal, original terms prevail.

Partial refunds/discounts applied by provider are final (cannot be
clawed back by provider through the UI).

If changes were forced outside rules (bug/abuse), Support can revert via
admin tools (audit trail shows all).

9\) Abuse & Rate Limits

Change attempt caps: e.g., max 3 pending proposals per booking at once.

Cooldowns if repeated declines.

Provider score impact for excessive late reschedule attempts; affects
search ranking and Instant Book eligibility.

10\) Examples (Concrete)

Provider shifts start time by 30 minutes (same day):

Buyer has autoapprove set to ±60 minutes → Instantly applied; ICS
updated.

Provider proposes moving shoot from Sat 10am to Sun 2pm:

Buyer must Accept/Decline; if decline, original remains; provider can
counter or cancel under policy.

Provider realizes commute is shorter; waives travel fee:

Applies immediately; buyer notified; escrow reduced; new receipt issued.

Buyer asks for 10 extra edited photos after the shoot:

Provider uses Add Extras → Buyer accepts → card charged → escrow up;
addendum stored.

Provider wants to upgrade to "Premium Package" price:

Sends Custom Offer Amendment → Buyer accepts → incremental charge;
deliverables updated; new PDF.

Shoot ended early (90 min vs 2 hours):

Provider issues partial refund (30 minutes); buyer notified; payout
reduced accordingly.

11\) Acceptance Criteria (QA)

Provider can initiate all actions above from "Manage Booking" with no
admin.

Consent rules enforced exactly as in matrix; autoapprove honored.

Amendments generated, versioned, and esigned where applicable; PDFs
attached.

Escrow & fees recompute correctly for increases/decreases and
afterpayout adjustments.

Locks prevent lastminute unilateral changes; proposals respect windows.

Calendars/ICS and notifications update on acceptance.

Audit trail shows who changed what, when, and why.

Abuse controls (caps, cooldowns, score impact) function.

12\) Why this works

Providers get full operational control (no support tickets).

Buyers retain consent over anything that costs them more or gives them
less.

The platform keeps money math and contracts accurate---minimizing
disputes.

Autoapprove rules + locks make the system fast but safe.

Addendum to §1.4 --- Storage & Deliverables (Large Files, External
Hosting, Feasibility) --- FINAL

Goal: Support professional photo/video delivery (including sets in the
tens/hundreds of GB) without the platform bearing heavy storage/egress
costs. Keep acceptance/disputes solid by capturing verifiable manifests
and reviewquality previews.

A\) Storage Model (Launch)

Hybrid by design

Small assets to platform (review quality): thumbnails, contact sheets,
lowres proxy video, PDFs; typical perfile cap ≤ 500 MB.

Originals offplatform (required for large sets): Google Drive, Dropbox,
OneDrive, Box, S3 presigned links owned by the provider.

External Delivery Modes (supported at launch)

OAuthconnected mode (preferred): Provider links Drive/Dropbox once. We
fetch file lists/metadata (name, size, modified, MIME, share URL),
generate a manifest and pin it to the booking.

Linkonly mode (no OAuth): Provider pastes share links (folder or file).
We crawl the listing (where permitted), and store a readonly manifest
(names/sizes/paths).

Checksum support: For platformuploaded items we compute hash; for
externals we store content length + etag (if available). Provider can
optionally paste SHA256 for each final file; we store/compare.

Review Previews (onplatform)

Photos: autogenerated webres JPEGs (e.g., long edge 2048px) for client
review.

Video: lowres proxy transcodes (e.g., 720p) for spotchecking length/cut;
no original uploads required.

Watermark policy: Watermarks allowed on previews; finals must be
watermarkfree (autocheck).

Retention & Liability

Platform stores previews + manifests for 365 days; not a longterm
archive.

Providers must keep external links intact for at least 30 days
postacceptance (and until dispute window closes); after that, retention
is their responsibility per contract.

Security & Access

Accepts tokenized share links and/passwordprotected links (password
stored encrypted).

We never mirror entire external folders by default. Limited, ephemeral
caching is allowed for preview generation only.

B\) Delivery Room Rules (updated)

Manifest is truth: Acceptance/disputes reference the pinned manifest
(counts/specs/filenames/sizes).

Spec autochecks: Count, MIME/codec, pixel dimensions, bitrate/duration,
color profile; flags must be cured before acceptance or go to dispute.

"All finals delivered" toggle: Provider asserts completeness; system
validates against manifest.

C\) Provider Responsibilities (contractual)

Keep external links accessible through the review & dispute windows.

Supply accurate manifests and, where feasible, checksums.

Ensure clientready files are present in the deliverables folder at
acceptance.

D\) Feasibility Notes (devlight)

OAuth scopes limited to readonly file metadata + download of preview
proxies; no destructive scopes.

Linkonly works dayone; OAuth can phase in.

For Drive/Dropbox API quotas, we ratelimit and cache manifests; fallback
to manual manifest upload if provider blocks API access.

E\) Acceptance Criteria

External delivery required for files \> 500 MB; platform generates and
pins manifests.

Preview generation for photos & proxies for video; watermark detection
on finals.

Retention banners & responsibilities shown; acceptance blocked if
required links are missing.

OAuth + linkonly ingestion; secure storage of tokens/passwords; no bulk
mirroring.

SubSection 1.5 --- Trust, Safety & Verification

Goal: Give every user confidence to book and meet new
collaborators---safely, transparently, and with minimal friction---while
protecting the marketplace from abuse, fraud, and policy risk. This spec
covers user verifications, badges, safety features, moderation,
enforcement, and operations.

A\) Principles

Safety first, friction last: Strong protections with the fewest possible
extra steps.

Visible trust: Clear verification badges and reputation signals where
users make decisions (search cards, profile headers, checkout).

Evidence by default: Contracts, chat logs, checkins, and delivery
artifacts form a reliable record for disputes and incident response.

Least privilege: Share the minimum personal info needed; keep private
data private.

Consistency: Predictable policies, transparent outcomes, and auditable
decisions.

B\) Policy Scope & User Eligibility

Age: Platform is 18+ only at launch (simplifies compliance and content
policies).

Geography: US launch; future locales require local backgroundcheck
availability and legal review.

Prohibited Conduct: Harassment, discrimination, hate, threats, illegal
activity, sexual services, escorting, doxxing, offplatform payment
solicitation, explicit sexual content onsite, intellectualproperty
violations.

Allowed Content (launch): SFW + artistic nudity with NSFW gating;
explicit sexual content disallowed onplatform. (Users may link to
external sites but uploaded media must comply.)

C\) The Verification Stack (levels, flows, incentives)

Design: Modular verifications with tangible benefits (search boost, DM
credits, InstantBook eligibility). Costs that require third parties are
passthrough or bundled in Pro.

C1. Baseline (free, encouraged)

Email Verified

Phone/SMS Verified

2FA (optional, recommended)

PaymentVerified (valid card/bank on file; required before taking
payouts)

Perks: +DM credits; minor search boost over unverified.

C2. Identity & Age (paid)

ID Verification (driver's license, passport) + selfie liveness

Face match against ID photo; age \>= 18 check

Required to unlock: Instant Book, Payouts, NSFW view/post\
Perks: Big search boost; more DM credits; "ID Verified" badge.

C3. Background Check (paid, optional "Trusted Pro")

National criminal + sexoffender registry check; rescreen annually.

Results are pass/fail for badge (details not shown).\
Perks: "Trusted Pro" badge; highest search tier; lower provider fee
incentive (per §1.3); increased DM credits.

C4. SocialVerified (free)

Connect Instagram Creator/Business, YouTube, TikTok to show verified
followers/engagement; optin which metrics index into search.\
Perks: "SocialVerified" badge; eligible for followers/ER filters; search
boost in creator/model categories.

C5. StudioVerified (optional)

Studio address + one supporting document; manual quick check.\
Perks: "Verified Studio" badge; appears in search filters ("studio
access: verified").

C6. ReferenceVerified (earned)

After N completed bookings with \>4★ average and low
cancellation/noshow, earn "Great Partner" ribbon.

UI: Badges appear on search cards and profile headers; hover tooltips
explain how each is earned.

D\) Safety Features (product)

D1. Safer Discovery

Filters: "ID Verified," "Trusted Pro," "SocialVerified," minimum rating,
low cancellation rate, response time.

Badges on Results: Always visible with short tooltips.

Profile Signals: Response time, completion rate, punctuality rate,
dispute rate (bucketed).

D2. Safer Booking & Meetup

Builtin contracts (booking agreement, model release, usage license)
autoattached and esigned.

Checkin/Checkout timestamps (optional); shared generalarea pin (50--150m
fuzzing) for privacy.

Trusted Contact (optional): share booking summary + checkin/out signals
with a private contact via secure link.

Location Tips: Premeeting banner: meet in public places or verified
studios for firsttime collaborations.

D3. Messaging Protections

Read receipts and last active to set expectations.

Automoderation for: slurs/harassment, sexual solicitations, payment
offplatform, contact info spam → inline warnings + throttles on repeat.

Block & Report (one tap) with categories and freetext; immediate mute on
both sides.

D4. Safety Flag & Triage

Prominent Safety Flag in booking threads.

Highpriority queue for Trust & Safety with SLA (e.g., triage within 2
business hours; faster during shoots).

When flagged: temporarily disable accused user's Instant Book and Smart
Invites until triage completes.

D5. Privacy Controls

Email/phone hidden by default; reveal toggle after booking (optional).

Media visibility: NSFW visibility requires optin; viewer must be 18+ and
ID Verified to view.

Anonymized handles available for public browsing (real name optional on
profile; legal name in contracts only).

E\) Moderation & Content Policy

E1. Upload Rules

No explicit sexual acts; no minors; no doxxing; no hate imagery; no
illegal items.

NSFW toggle required where applicable; autodetection queues borderline
content for human review.

E2. Review Integrity

Reviews allowed only after completed bookings.

Noshow participants can still be reviewed with a system label ("Noshow
reported by counterparty").

Reports against reviews trigger moderation (defamation, irrelevance,
hate). Uphold facts tied to bookings.

E3. Enforcement Ladder

Education & warning

Temporary feature limits (DM caps, Instant Book disabled)

Timeboxed suspension

Removal and device/account ban

Strike policy: late cancels, noshows, policy violation content/messages;
expiry after X months.

F\) Fraud, Risk & Account Integrity

Risk scoring at signup and on each transaction: device fingerprint, IP
geolocation, velocity checks, mismatched card/name signals.

KYC for payouts: ID Verified + bank account name matching.

Hold & reserves: Higher reserve or payout delay for new/untrusted
accounts, relaxing with reputation.

Duplicate accounts / ban evasion: Device & identity correlation; block
on detection.

Chargeback defense: Autoassemble evidence packet (contracts, chat,
checkins, deliverables logs).

Anticircumvention: Heuristic detection of offplatform payments →
warnings → throttles → suspensions for repeat.

G\) Operations Playbook (internal)

Triage Matrix:

Safety & abuse (SLA fast) → specialized agents

Content moderation → queue with priority for NSFW edge cases

ID/Background verifications → automated + manual exceptions

Fraud/chargebacks → risk team with template evidence

Evidence Retention:

Booking artifacts (contracts, chat logs, checkins, deliverables
manifest) retained 12--24 months; extend on dispute.

PII access limited to T&S and finance staff via rolebased permissions.

Transparency & Appeals:

Users get a decision summary for major actions (what policy, what
evidence).

Appeals allowed once per action except for extreme cases (e.g., verified
criminal activity onplatform).

H\) Incentives that Make Safety "Pay"

Search boost tiers: ID Verified \> SocialVerified \> Trusted Pro
(highest).

DM credit boosts: +5 (phone), +10 (ID), unlimited newconversation
credits for Trusted Pro.

Fee perks (from §1.3): small provider fee reduction for Trusted Pro;
Instant Book discount.

Feature unlocks: Instant Book requires ID Verified; Autoaccept + Smart
Invites require ID Verified (and higher limits for Trusted Pro).

I\) UserFacing Safety Center

Guides: First shoot safety checklist, how to use contracts, what to do
if you feel unsafe, scam red flags.

Policies: Clear, nonlegalese summaries with links to full terms.

Contact support: Safety hotline (email/chat) with stated SLAs; emergency
escalation instructions.

Incident report form: Structured; encourages timely, detailed reporting.

J\) MVP vs Phase2

MVP

18+ only, baseline verifications (email/phone), ID verification to
unlock payouts/NSFW/Instant Book

Optional Background Check ("Trusted Pro")

SocialVerified (connect IG/YT/TT)

NSFW gating & automoderation for uploads/messages

Safety flag, block/report, checkin/out timestamps

Enforcement ladder & strike logic; evidence retention minimums

Risk scoring + payout holds for new providers

Phase2

Trusted Contact livelinks & realtime safety pings

Devicelevel ban evasion detection refinements

Brand safety scoring for creators (keyword/image sentiment on linked
social posts)

Inthread identity recheck (selfie prompt) for suspicious flows

City "safe studios" network curation and promotion

Verified reference letters (offplatform clients/agencies with proof)

K\) Metrics & Alarms (what we measure)

Trust adoption: % ID Verified, % Trusted Pro, % SocialVerified

Safety outcomes: incident rate per 100 bookings, average timetotriage,
repeat offender rate

Reliability: cancellation/noshow rates, ontime rates, response time
medians

Fraud: chargeback rate, offplatform attempt rate, duplicate account hits

Impact: uplift in booking conversion for verified vs nonverified;
dispute rates by verification tier

Guardrail alarms: Incident spike over baseline, surge in offplatform
attempts, sudden drop in verification pass rates, abnormal dispute
clustering.

L\) Acceptance Criteria (for engineering & ops)

Badge system live with Email/Phone/2FA, ID, Background, Social, Studio,
Reference statuses and UI tooltips.

Search filters & ranking incorporate verification tiers and reliability
signals.

NSFW gating + automoderation for uploads/messages; human review queue
operational.

Safety Flag → highpriority triage with suppression of Instant Book for
accused until triage.

Checkin/out timestamps; optional generalarea pin; privacy defaults
respected.

Enforcement ladder & strike counters with expirations; audit log of
actions.

Risk scoring, payout holds/reserves for new accounts; KYC gating before
payouts.

Evidence retention and export for disputes/chargebacks.

Safety Center content published; support SLA timers visible to ops.

M\) Why this will work

Visible trust reduces hesitation and increases conversion.

ID/Background checks + contracts make inperson shoots feel professional
and safe.

Automoderation + incentives keep money onplatform and lower support
load.

Evidencefirst approach shrinks dispute duration and chargeback loss.

Addendum to §1.5 (Trust)\
Trust, Safety & Verification

Recommendation: Insert these as new subsections after your existing
verification stack and safety features (e.g., §1.5.G → §1.5.K). Leave
any search UI behavior in §1.2; keep definitions, badges, scoring,
safety flows here.

§1.5.G Studio & Location Verification

Studio Verified (badge): owner uploads address + supporting document
(lease/utility/biz registration). Staff performs a onetime check. Badge
appears on profile; exposed to search as "Studio access: verified."

Booking Location Verification (optional at checkout):

If buyer selects a known verified studio, no extra step.

Private addresses remain private; after acceptance, provider may request
location verification (lightweight place check). If unresolvable, show a
warning to both parties.

Touring calendar (from §1.2 travel): pairs well with verified studios
for safer first meetings.

§1.5.H References

Verified References (auto): created from completed onplatform bookings
(role + date). Contribute to reputation score.

Community References (optional): past collaborators can submit a
reference; recipient must approve; platform lightverifies metadata
(e.g., linked post/file). Lower weight; clearly labeled.

Search tiein: §1.2 exposes "Has verified references (≥ N)" filter.

§1.5.I Reputation Score (0--100)

Purpose: oneglance confidence, without replacing detailed info.

Formula v1 (roleaware, timeweighted):

Reviews & volume (rolespecific) --- 40%

Reliability (ontime, completion, noshow, dispute rate) --- 25%

Responsiveness (median first response time; consistency) --- 10%

Verifications (ID, Background, SocialVerified, Studio) --- 15%

Recent performance (last 90 days) --- 10%\
Negative events (late cancels, noshows, dispute losses) reduce sharply
and decay over time.

Display:

Score ring + "Why this score?" breakdown.

Rolespecific and overall values (use role score in role search).

New users show "New --- building reputation" (no penalty for being new).

Search tiein: §1.2 adds Min Rep Score filter and Top Reputation sort;
Rep used as tiebreaker after core relevance factors.

Gaming protections: weight by review volume and recency; cap any one
factor; monitor anomalies.

§1.5.J Safety Expansions

Trusted Contact link (optional): share booking summary + checkin/out
timestamps with a designated contact via secure link.

Generalarea location share (100--150m fuzzing) during active bookings;
clear "stop sharing."

Preshoot safety tips injected into chat 24h before firsttime meetings.

Autosuppress Instant Book during active safety investigations.

Privacy for highprofile users: alias display names; reveal precise
address only after confirmation.

§1.5.K Acceptance Criteria (Trust addendum)

Studio Verified badge live; optional booking location verification flow.

References: both Verified (auto) and Community (approval + lower weight)
displayed and factored into reputation.

Reputation Score computed, explained, visible (role & overall), and
emitted as a signal to §1.2 for filters/sorting.

Safety enhancements: trusted contact, areashare, preshoot tips, and
InstantBook suppression are implemented.

Addendum --- §1.5 Trust & Safety (Studios) --- FINAL

Goal: Define clear, studiospecific safety, verification, privacy, and
policy rules that protect buyers, hosts, and talent---without diluting
our artisticonly content policy or Safe Mode behavior. Keep enforcement
predictable and tooling light.

A\) Policy Scope & Definitions (Studios)

Studio = Space Listing (placebased). Trust controls apply to the space,
not a person's role.

Host = Account owner of a Studio listing.

Buyer = The party renting the studio (may be a brand, photographer, or
creator).

Artisticonly policy applies to all bookings: onplatform bookings may
include artistic nudity; explicit sexual content/acts are prohibited (no
adult content production facilitated or booked through the platform).

B\) What We Verify (Studio Lite)

Address & Ownership/RighttoRent: government/utility/lease doc + name
match; geocode/place match.

Basic Safety Disclosures: max occupancy, egress, rules summary (noise,
strobe, haze, open flame, ladders).

Host Identity: host must be IDVerified; background checks (Trusted Pro)
remain peoplerole only.

Badge: passing shows Verified Studio.

Note: Studio Lite is not a building inspection or insurance substitute;
it's a light authenticity & disclosure check.

C\) Required Documents & Gating (per booking)

Smart Docs autoattach for Studio bookings:

Property/Space Release (host ↔ buyer)

House Rules (host authored; standardized fields)

Safety Addendum (if strobe/haze/open flame indicated)

Esign before checkin: access instructions (door code) unlock only after
signatures.

Minors: if talent under 18, Minor/Guardian Release required (already in
§3.5/§3.7); studios can display "No minors" if host policy forbids.

D\) Safe Mode & Visibility

Safe Mode (18+) affects people profiles and feed content, not studio
visibility.

Studio photos and copy must remain SFW (no explicit imagery). It's
acceptable to reference "suitable for fineart nude photography" if
aligned with policy.

E\) OnSite Safety & Conduct (baseline)

Arrival & Checkin: geofenced checkin/out required for dispute
protection.

Chaperones: allowed unless host rules prohibit (hosts must state policy
clearly).

Boundaries: all onset conduct must respect talent boundaries and house
rules; harassment → immediate removal & Safety action.

Loadin/out & Crew Limit: must be honored; overages handled via
PostBooking Adjustment workflow.

Prohibited: explicit sexual acts, hate content, weapons discharge,
pyrotechnics (unless permitted & declared), illegal substances.

F\) Privacy, Cameras & Sensitive Areas

Surveillance disclosure required: hosts must disclose all cameras (fixed
or smart).

No cameras in bathrooms, dressing/makeup rooms, or other private
areas---strict violation.

Consent signage: if any camera is present in a nonprivate area, host
must display a "recording in progress" sign.

Audio recording: must be disclosed; recording conversations without
consent is prohibited where unlawful.

G\) Access, Security & Emergency

Access methods: keypad/concierge/hostmeet; share instructions
postsigning.

Emergency contact: host phone provided postbooking; platform emergency
contact tile present in thread for P0 safety use.

Incident triage: Safety P0 (threat, medical, harassment) → immediate
hotline; IB & boosts suppressed pending review.

H\) Hazard & SpecialUse Disclosures

Required rule toggles: strobe, haze/fog, loud audio, open flame,
ladders/scaffolds, wet floors, heavy props.

If toggled: Smart Docs adds Safety Addendum & checklist; buyer must
acknowledge and assume responsibility to follow posted procedures.

Open flame/pyro: disallowed unless local permits uploaded (attachment
field) and host allows.

I\) Accessibility & Accuracy

Accessibility attributes: stepfree access, elevator, restroom type, door
widths, parking.

Hosts must not misrepresent accessibility; repeated inaccuracies →
listing suppression and strike.

J\) Insurance & Deposits (clarity)

We do not provide insurance at launch. Hosts may require a COI upload
(optional field in booking thread).

Damage deposit (card hold): explained to buyer prepay; captured only on
approved claim (per §3.1/§3.9).

No platform fee on deposit captures; abuse (frivolous claims) →
penalties.

K\) AntiDiscrimination & Inclusion

Standard marketplace antidiscrimination applies to studio access
(protected classes).

Service animals: must be allowed where legally required; disclosure
needed for allergysensitive environments.

L\) Enforcement & Strikes (studiospecific)

Strikeworthy: hidden cameras / privatearea cameras, undisclosed
surveillance, unsafe conditions knowingly concealed, explicit content
facilitation, repeated access failures, repeated misrepresentation of
amenities/accessibility.

Interim measures: Instant Book disable, paid promotion suppression,
search throttling.

Remedies: require listing edits, additional disclosures, or verification
recheck.

Removal: severe or repeated violations → delist studio and potential
account suspension.

M\) Safety UX Hooks (lightweight)

Preshoot tips injected to the thread 24h prior ("Bring a chaperone if
preferred," "Share trusted contact," "Review house rules").

Trusted contact link: share session times & generalarea location with a
designated contact (fuzzed to 100--150m).

Safety banner on studio detail page: "Read House Rules & emergency exit
info on arrival."

N\) Acceptance Criteria (mark §1.5 addendum FINAL)

Studio Lite verification requirements documented and enforced
(address/righttorent + disclosures + host ID).

Smart Docs (Property/Space Release, House Rules, Safety Addendum when
applicable) autoattach; esign gating before access.

Safe Mode leaves studios visible; studio media SFWonly enforced in
uploader/moderation.

Surveillance & privacy rules enforced: disclosure required; no cameras
in private areas; signage for any recording.

Hazard toggles present; Safety Addendum injected when toggled; pyro/open
flame restricted without permits.

Accessibility fields added; misrepresentation enforcement path defined.

Emergency hooks (hotline, oncall), IB/boost suppression during
investigations.

Enforcement ladder (strike types, interim measures, removal)
implemented.

KB updates: "Studio Lite verification," "House Rules & Property
Release," "Cameras & privacy," "Hazards & permits," "Deposits & claims,"
"Artisticonly policy for studios."

O\) Why this works

Clear, minimal, enforceable: focuses on truths we can verify (address,
rules, cameras, hazards), not subjective promises.

Protects users & brand: artisticonly boundary, privacy rules, and strike
ladder guard against the highestrisk scenarios.

Lowlift ops: Lite verification + templated docs + hazard toggles keep
support scalable while giving buyers predictable safety signals.

SubSection 1.6 --- Support, Help Center & Knowledge Base

Goal: Resolve user issues fast, fairly, and consistently---with the
lowest support overhead possible. Blend selfserve (knowledge base,
guided flows, inproduct smart prompts) with human support that's
roleaware (Model/Photographer/Videographer/Creator), bookingaware, and
safetyfirst.

A\) Principles

Selfserve first: Articles, guided troubleshooters, and contextual
prompts resolve 70%+ without tickets.

Inthread resolution: Most issues are solved inside the booking thread
(refunds, extras, schedule changes) via action cards, not email
pingpong.

Safety & money prioritized: Safety; payment capture/escrow;
noshow/cancellation; disputes get elevated handling.

One source of truth: Contracts, chat, amendments, deliverables, and
receipts are the evidence for decisions.

Consistency over heroics: Clear policies, macros, and audit trails keep
outcomes predictable and defensible.

B\) UserFacing Support Channels

Help Center (web + mobile web)

Public, SEOfriendly articles; rolefiltered navigation; search with
synonyms and typotolerance.

"Was this helpful?" feedback; related articles; contact support CTA if
unresolved.

InProduct Help Widget

Contextual launcher on key pages (Search, Profile editor, Checkout,
Messaging/Project Panel).

Surfaces top articles + guided flows (see §C).

Booking Thread → "Get help"

One tap opens guided issue forms that preattach the booking ID and
autopulls context (policy chosen, timestamps, files exchanged).

Safety Flag lives here too (escalates directly to T&S).

Email form (fallback)

Web form that collects role, booking ID, category, severity; captures
device + browser autometadata.

(No phone support at launch; consider for enterprise later.)

C\) Guided Flows (Decision Trees)

Purpose: Solve or autoprepare the case before an agent sees it.

Payments & Payouts

"Charge failed" → suggest retry/readd method → if still failing, create
ticket tagged BILLING with last 4 of card, error code.

"Where is my payout?" → show payout timeline & status → if past SLA,
open PAYOUTDELAY with booking and bankonfile.

Reschedule/Cancel

Walks buyer/provider through policy windows; if within selfserve rules,
triggers Reschedule or Cancel action card directly.

If outofpolicy, collects reason and evidence → creates EXCEPTIONREQUEST.

Noshow/Late

Collects proof (checkin/out, chat logs); autocomputes default outcome
per policy; if contested, opens DISPUTE with attached evidence.

Deliverables/Quality

For missing finals: prompts provider to upload; starts a 24--48h timer;
opens MISSINGDELIVERABLES if timer expires.

For quality complaints: gathers specifics (what vs. agreed); suggests
partial settlement; creates QUALITYDISPUTE if unresolved.

Verification

ID verification help (photo tips, doc types); retries; escalates
IDVMANUALREVIEW only if necessary.

Background check status and rescreen schedule.

Account/Safety

Harassment/abuse → SAFETYPRIORITY; throttles accused user's Instant Book
automatically until triage.

Takedown (copyright/defamation) → structured DMCA/CONTENTREPORT intake.

D\) Ticket Taxonomy & Priority

Categories (toplevel): BILLING, PAYOUT, BOOKINGCHANGE, CANCELLATION,
NOSHOW, DISPUTE, DELIVERABLES, VERIFICATIONID, VERIFICATIONBG, SAFETY,
CONTENTREPORT, TECHNICAL, ACCOUNTACCESS.

Priorities:

P0: Active safety incident; live shoot at risk; payment capture failure
during checkout.

P1: Imminent shoot (\<24h) with conflict; payout stuck \> SLA; noshow
reports within 24h.

P2: Disputes, cancellations, verification issues, content reports.

P3: General questions, feature requests, minor bugs.

SLAs (initial):

P0: 1 hour triage; 4 hours to first action.

P1: 4 business hours first response; 24--48h resolution target.

P2: 1 business day first response; 3--5 days resolution.

P3: 2 business days first response.

(Business hours: Mon--Fri 9a--6p CT. Safety P0 monitored extended hours
during ramp.)

E\) Refunds, Credits & Adjustments (Ops Playbook)

Selfserve inside thread (preferred): Providermanaged partial/full
refunds and discounts per §1.4 addendum; autorecompute escrow, fees,
tax; amended receipts issued.

Platforminitiated refunds (edge cases):

Noshow (provider) → 100% refund to buyer, provider strike.

Fraudulent payment → full refund if chargeback; account restrictions.

Safety violations → casebycase per policy.

Credit vs. cash

Credits (nonexpiring) for goodwill when cash refund not mandated; show
credit balance at checkout; credits never convert to cash.

Cash refunds follow processor timelines; fees refunded per processor
policy.

Nonrefundable expenses

If buyer preapproved longhaul expenses and provider purchased
tickets/hotel → those are nonrefundable unless provider cancels.
Evidence (receipts) stored with booking.

F\) Knowledge Base (IA, Writing Standards)

Information Architecture (roleaware gateways):

Getting Started (per role: Model, Photographer, Videographer, Creator)

Profiles & Verification (ID, Background, Social connections, Studio
verification)

Search & Discovery (filters, engagement metrics explained, reputation
score)

Booking & Payments (packages, extras, escrow, licensing tiers)

Travel & Locations (travel fees, longhaul rules, touring calendar,
studio verification)

Messaging & Collaboration (moodboard, shot list, call sheet,
deliverables)

Cancellations & Disputes (policies, evidence examples, timelines)

Safety & Policies (Safety flag, checkin/out, content rules, reporting)

Troubleshooting & Technical (uploads, file limits, notifications,
calendar)

Fees & Taxes (commission, buyer fee, payouts, yearend docs)

Article pattern:

Ataglance (what you'll learn)

Steps (numbered, screenshots)

FAQs

Related (deep links to actions in product)

Tone: clear, nonlegalese, rolespecific examples, short paragraphs, bold
key phrases.

Maintenance:

Monthly review of top 50 articles; rotate "What's new"; deprecate stale
content on feature changes.

G\) Internal Tools & Automation

Agent console (or vendor helpdesk) with:

Booking lookup (contracts, chat, amendments, receipts, checkins, files).

Oneclick outcomes: refund %, credit issue, disable Instant Book, apply
strike, request more info.

Macros and reply snippets per category/role; dynamic placeholders
(names, dates, amounts).

Attachment redaction (PII), secure file links.

Automations:

Autoroute by category/priority → BILLING/PAYOUT to finance queue; SAFETY
to T&S.

SLA timers and breach alerts; oncall paging for P0.

Deflection suggestions from KB; if user still clicks "Contact support",
attach read article IDs to ticket.

Quality checks: random 5% of closed tickets for QA review (macro
adherence, empathy, correctness).

H\) Policy Playbooks (summary cards for agents)

NoShow/Late: decision tree (proof priority: checkin/out \> chat \>
3rdparty evidence).

Deliverables missing: 24--48h cure period → partial refund ladder if
continued failure.

Quality disputes: compare against package spec + sample images; propose
partial refund tiers; escalate if \>\$X requested.

Safety: immediate suppression of risky features on accused; collect
details; document local law guidance (no legal advice).

Fraud/Chargeback: compile evidence pack (contracts, chat, timestamps,
IP/device, deliverable checksums).

Content takedowns: DMCA intake; remove if valid; counternotice flow;
repeat offenders.

I\) Metrics & Targets (dashboards)

Containment rate (selfserve solved / total contacts) --- target ≥ 70%

FRT (first response time) by priority --- P1 ≤ 4h, P2 ≤ 1 day

TTR (time to resolution) by category

CSAT (postticket), NPS (quarterly)

Reopen rate, Escalation rate, SLA breach count

Safety incident rate per 100 bookings; dispute rate; chargeback rate

Cost per ticket; tickets per 100 bookings (aim to decline as product
matures)

Ops cadence: Weekly review of top drivers; monthly policy/macro tuneups;
quarterly staffing forecast.

J\) Accessibility & Localization

Accessibility: All help content screenreader friendly; transcripts for
video guides; highcontrast mode.

Localization: US English at launch; prepare IA for future locales
(date/time norms, payout terms vary).

K\) MVP vs Phase2

MVP

Help Center with IA above; inproduct widget; guided flows for top 8
categories

Ticketing with priorities, SLAs, macros; evidencefirst booking context

Selfserve refunds/discounts in thread (providermanaged); platform
refunds for edge cases

Safety flag priority queue; autosuppress Instant Book during
investigations

Core metrics dashboards (containment, FRT/TTR, CSAT, incident/dispute
rates)

Phase2

Phone support for enterprise; chat support for P1 windows

AI answer suggestions + autodraft macros; article quality scoring

Proactive alerts (e.g., "payout delay spike") with status page banners

Webhooks to status page; incident comms templates

Automated "nextbest action" in booking threads (e.g., suggest partial
refund based on delay)

L\) Acceptance Criteria (for engineering & ops)

Help Center live with IA above; rolefiltered nav; feedback on articles;
"contact support" handoff.

Inproduct Help Widget present on Search, Profile, Checkout, Messaging;
serves contextual top articles.

Booking thread Get Help opens guided flows; creates tickets prefilled
with booking context when needed.

Ticket system supports categories, priorities, SLAs, macros; routes to
correct queues; tracks metrics.

Agents can see complete booking evidence and trigger outcomes
(refunds/credits/strikes) with audit logs.

Safety flag pipeline active: P0 triage \< 1 hour; Instant Book
autosuppressed for accused until triage.

Selfserve provider refunds/discounts update escrow, fees, taxes, and
receipts automatically.

Dashboards show containment, FRT/TTR, CSAT/NPS,
incident/dispute/chargeback rates; weekly export.

Accessibility checks pass; critical articles cover top 80% of issues.

M\) Why this works

Users solve most problems themselves (clear content + guided flows) →
less friction, faster outcomes.

Bookingaware support avoids repeated questions; agents act with full
context.

Safety & money get priority, with evidencefirst decisions that stand up
to disputes and chargebacks.

Macros and playbooks deliver consistency, speed, and fairness---scaling
support without scaling cost.

Section 2 --- GotoMarket & City Launch Plan

Expanding the business city by city requires a structured go-to-market
strategy combined with a detailed launch plan for each new location.
Successful geographic expansion is grounded in clear metrics, phased
milestones, and effective knowledge transfer to local teams. In this
section, we outline a comprehensive plan for entering new cities, from
initial market research through post-launch optimization, ensuring each
launch is executed efficiently and sets the stage for sustainable
growth.

2.1 Market Research & City Selection

Before committing to any city launch, we will conduct in-depth market
research to select the right city and prepare a data-driven entry
strategy. Key factors to research include:

Local Market Demographics: Understand the target city's population
characteristics and customer segments to ensure our product resonates
with local needs.

Competitive Landscape: Identify existing competitors or alternatives in
the city and benchmark their offerings and market share. This analysis
will highlight gaps we can fill and help position our service
effectively.

Regulatory and Legal Requirements: Check for any city-specific licenses,
permits, or regulations that could affect operations. For example, some
cities may require special permits for our services that we don't need
in current markets, and we must secure these in advance to launch
legally and smoothly.

Operational Fit: Assess whether our current business model and processes
will work in the new city, or if we need adaptations. This is especially
crucial for an expansion into a very different market or culture.

In addition to the above, financial viability will be evaluated for each
potential city. We will forecast the launch and operating costs versus
projected revenues to ensure the expansion makes economic sense. Only
cities that show a healthy opportunity (sufficient target customers and
manageable competitive pressure) will be chosen for launch.

Upfront preparation is also critical. Prior to expansion, we will
establish a clear set of Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and document
standard processes as the foundation for all city launches. These KPIs
(e.g. customer acquisition rate, monthly active users, local revenue,
etc.) define what success looks like in a new city. They enable us to
set measurable milestones for the launch (such as acquiring a certain
number of users or providers within the first 3 months). By having a
predefined KPI framework and playbook, we ensure each city launch is
measured consistently and can be managed against the same performance
benchmarks. Thorough documentation of processes (and automation where
possible) will allow rapid knowledge transfer to new teams and maintain
consistency as we replicate our model in different locales.\
\
2.2 Launch Team & Local Operations Setup

To execute the city launch plan effectively, we will deploy a dedicated
city launch team and set up local operations in advance. Rather than
expecting each new city to figure things out independently, a specialist
launch team from the company will temporarily relocate to spearhead the
launch on the ground. This team may include experienced members from our
existing operations along with specialists (e.g. marketing, community
managers) who focus on new launches. Crucially, the team will include a
recruiter or HR lead who arrives about six weeks early in the target
city to start lining up local hires before the official launch period.
Hiring a local city manager and key operational staff in advance ensures
that when we launch, we have people who know the area and can eventually
take over daily operations.

During the initial weeks in a new city, the launch team will handle
tasks like securing any physical requirements (for example, a small
local office or storage facility if needed) and ensuring all logistics
and regulatory prerequisites are in place. This includes confirming
local permits or licenses have been obtained (as identified in the
research phase) and setting up any local partnerships or vendor
relationships needed for operations (e.g. local supply vendors,
last-mile logistics, etc.). Compliance with city regulations and laws
will be a priority before launch day, so that we enter the market on the
right side of local requirements.

We recognize that hiring the right local talent is pivotal to success in
a new market. The local team will ultimately run the city's operations
after the launch team leaves, so we will take care to recruit
high-quality, proactive individuals who can operate with some autonomy.
Especially if the new city is far from headquarters, we need employees
who are self-starters and don't require constant hand-holding. We will
not rush the hiring process or settle for sub-par candidates simply to
fill positions quickly; bringing on the right people (even if it takes a
bit more time) will pay off in smoother operations and better growth
post-launch. The recruiter on the launch team will focus on assembling
this local team early, so they can train alongside the launch experts
during the rollout period.

In summary, our go-to-market plan calls for a skilled launch taskforce
to establish each new city, build out local operations, and hand over a
well-functioning business to a carefully hired local team. By
front-loading the operational setup and knowledge transfer, we set each
city up with the tools, people, and processes it needs to thrive from
day one.

2.3 Localized Marketing & Customer Acquisition Strategy

A one-size-fits-all marketing approach will not work for city launches
--- each new city requires a localized go-to-market strategy tailored to
its audience and culture. Our marketing plan for city launches will
combine overarching brand messaging with hyper-local tactics to quickly
build awareness and user adoption in the new market.

First, we will leverage digital marketing targeted to the specific city.
This includes geo-targeted online ads (social media, search engines)
focused on the city's residents, and localized content on our website or
app store listings highlighting why our product/service is a great fit
for that city. We will also pursue local media coverage and PR
opportunities (press releases, local news features) to announce our
launch and explain the unique value we bring to the community.

Beyond digital channels, on-the-ground and community-focused marketing
will be key. We plan to engage in grassroots promotion such as
city-specific launch events, pop-up demos, or sponsorships. For example,
if launching a new service in a city, we might host a launch day event
or partner with a popular local festival to showcase our offering.
Forming partnerships with local businesses or influencers can greatly
accelerate word-of-mouth. One proven tactic is to go directly where our
target customers already congregate. For instance, when Oatly expanded
into a new market, they bypassed generic ads and partnered with local
coffee shops to reach their ideal customers at the point of purchase, a
strategy credited with helping their product gain rapid adoption (10x
revenue growth in one year). We will identify similar win-win
partnership opportunities in each city (whether it's coffee shops,
community centers, universities, or other venues relevant to our target
demographic) to embed our product into the local lifestyle from the
start.

Our customer acquisition playbook in each city will be experimental and
responsive to local feedback. Each city has a unique culture and what
works in one market may not work in another. To account for this, we
will be prepared to test and iterate on marketing channels quickly.
Early in the launch, the team will test a range of channels -- e.g.
social media campaigns, flyer distributions in high-traffic areas,
referral incentives, collaborations with local influencers -- and double
down on those that show traction. As one startup founder notes from
experience, it's important to "cycle through different customer
acquisition approaches because every new market is different", and to
spend time on the ground learning "what makes a city tick" by seeing
things from the local's perspective. In practice, this could mean our
team spends the first couple of weeks immersing in the city's daily
life, talking to potential users, and understanding their needs and
habits.

We will also deploy creative grassroots tactics to spark initial
word-of-mouth. For example, one company found success by physically
going to a local flea market right after launch and pitching their
product directly to shoppers who fit their target profile, essentially
bringing the product to the customer at a point of need. In our case,
we'll seek out comparable opportunities (whether it's attending meetups,
weekend markets, or neighborhood events) to personally introduce our
service to early adopters. Such high-touch efforts not only drive early
user sign-ups but also show the community that we are invested and
engaged locally.

All these marketing efforts will be coordinated to create a surge of
awareness and adoption around the launch period. We aim to achieve a
critical mass of users in the first weeks, which will attract further
users through network effects and social proof. By combining targeted
digital campaigns with on-the-ground engagement and partnerships, our
go-to-market strategy ensures that each city launch quickly gains
momentum and establishes our brand firmly in the local market.

2.4 Launch Timeline & Milestones

Executing a city launch will be done in phases with clear timelines and
milestones to keep the team on track. We will use a milestone-based city
launch plan that breaks the process into manageable stages from
pre-launch through post-launch. Below is an outline of the launch
timeline for each city:

Pre-Launch Preparation (T-minus 6 Weeks): Approximately six weeks before
the public launch, our advance team (especially the recruiter) is on the
ground in the new city. Key activities in this phase include finalizing
local hires, securing any necessary office space or equipment, meeting
with prospective partners, and launching initial teaser marketing (e.g.
"coming soon" campaigns). By the end of this phase, we aim to have a
trained local core team in place and all major operational issues
resolved before full launch.

Launch Execution (Weeks 1--4 of Launch): This marks the official launch
period when our service becomes available in the city. The city launch
team arrives in full to execute the playbook. In the first 4 weeks, the
team focuses on hitting early milestones: onboarding initial customers
and/or service providers, ensuring service quality, and monitoring KPIs
closely (for example, reaching a target number of active users or
transactions by week 4). During this phase, the launch team works
hands-on alongside the new local hires, demonstrating processes and
solving problems in real time. We maintain a checklist of critical
milestones (e.g. system infrastructure stable, first 100 customers
acquired, first local partnership deal signed, customer satisfaction
above threshold) that should be achieved by the end of Week 4. Hitting
these targets confirms the launch is gaining traction as expected.

Knowledge Transfer & Transition (Weeks 5--10): Around week 5, once the
initial launch goals are met, the focus shifts to transferring full
operational control to the local team. From Week 5 through Week 10, the
city launch team gradually steps back while coaching the local team to
handle all aspects of the business. During this transition, standard
operating procedures are reviewed, and any local adjustments are
documented. The launch team ensures the new team is comfortable with
maintaining quality and growth. By about the tenth week, our goal is
that the local team can run the city independently, with the central
launch team only in a support role. A final review is done at Week 10 to
decide if the city is on track (meeting the KPI targets set out) and if
the launch team can fully exit to focus on the next city.

Each phase has explicit milestones and deliverables, allowing us to
track progress and address issues promptly. This milestone-based
approach creates accountability and clarity -- everyone knows what
"success" looks like at each stage of the launch. If a milestone is not
met (for example, if user acquisition falls short in Week 2-3), the team
can pause and troubleshoot or deploy additional resources to fix the
issue before proceeding. By structuring the city launch in phases, we
ensure a disciplined rollout and reduce the risk of launching without
the necessary foundations in place.

2.5 Post-Launch Monitoring & Scaling Strategy

Launching in a new city is not the end of the process -- it's the
beginning of that city's growth journey. After the initial launch and
handoff, we will have systems in place to monitor performance, support
the local team, and continuously improve our expansion playbook for
future cities.

Firstly, we will set up a city monitoring function to oversee the health
of all launched cities. This could be a small centralized team or a
regular review process that uses our KPI framework to track each city's
metrics (e.g. growth rate, revenue, customer satisfaction) against
targets. The purpose is to ensure consistency and quality across cities,
catching any post-launch issues early. We may implement standard
compliance checks or quality audits (akin to an internal "city
operations QA" program) to verify that each city is maintaining our
service standards. For example, using a common framework or dashboard,
we can compare metrics across cities to identify any outliers or best
practices. If one city is excelling in a particular area (say, very high
customer retention), those tactics can be shared with other cities.

We will also encourage an environment of continuous knowledge sharing
among city teams. As the Times of India notes, effective expansion
relies on teams being "independent as well as centrally aligned and
sharing best practices". To facilitate this, we'll hold regular
cross-city meetings or calls (for instance, a bi-weekly "city leads
sync") where city managers exchange learnings, challenges, and
successes. We will maintain an internal knowledge repository (wiki or
playbook documents) that gets updated with insights from each launch --
this may include refining checklists, marketing tactics that worked, or
pitfalls to avoid. These updates will continuously enhance our city
launch playbook. In fact, each new city provides an opportunity to
improve the model: for example, after launching in our second city, we
might refine our onboarding process or marketing strategy based on what
we learned, creating an even stronger template for the third city. Over
time, this accumulation of experience becomes a powerful asset, making
subsequent launches more predictable and efficient.

Another post-launch strategy is to foster some exchange of talent for
training and culture. We can have experienced team members from a
successful city spend time in a newer city to mentor the local team or
help instill best practices, and vice versa. This cross-pollination
ensures that our company's culture and standards are consistently
spread, and it gives rising local stars a chance to learn in different
environments.

Finally, our expansion plan will take a sustainable growth approach. We
will only scale up to the next cities when ready, rather than launching
too many cities all at once. It's important to avoid the trap of growing
too fast, too soon, which can strain resources and lead to quality
control issues. Each city launch will be evaluated against its KPIs to
ensure it's stable (operationally and financially) before we green-light
the next launch. This paced expansion prevents high cash burn and
employee burnout that can come from aggressive, uncontrolled expansion.
By making sure we have the necessary resources (funding, people,
technology) in place for each new market, we protect the quality of our
service and brand reputation as we grow.

In summary, the post-launch phase focuses on consolidating success,
maintaining standards, and preparing for the next expansion. We will
continuously monitor each city's performance and support the teams to
ensure ongoing success. Lessons learned will feed back into our
go-to-market strategy, allowing us to refine our approach with every new
city. This feedback loop and careful scaling strategy will enable us to
confidently expand our footprint city by city, while delivering a
consistent, high-quality experience in every market we serve.

Our go-to-market rollout will be executed in clearly defined phases with
measurable milestones. Phase 1 (current phase) covers our initial launch
in our first city (or region), which establishes our beachhead and
refines our core service. Assuming Section 1 covered the success of our
pilot market, we are now leveraging those learnings to expand further.
Phase 2 will consist of launching in the next set of high-priority
cities (Tier 1 markets from our selection process). We anticipate
launching in X new cities in the first 6 months of expansion, focusing
on cities that scored highest on our opportunity scorecard (for example,
\[City A\], \[City B\], and \[City C\]). These initial expansions are
milestone-driven: before moving on, we aim for each new city to achieve
key targets such as reaching Y active users and attaining a baseline
revenue or engagement level that proves local viability.

Phase 3 will expand to Tier 2 markets -- a broader set of cities once
the playbook is validated in Phase 2. In this phase (perhaps months 6-18
of the plan), we might roll out to an additional N cities each quarter,
accelerating our coverage. Here we apply our tiered strategy: some
cities might be in \"launch mode\" focusing on user acquisition and
refining unit economics, while others (including our earliest markets)
graduate to \"growth mode\". Importantly, we will set different goals
for different stages: for example, a city in its first 3 months of
launch may target customer acquisition and awareness as the primary
KPIs, whereas a city in month 12 may target repeat usage and
profitability. Our plan explicitly accounts for these stage-based goals.
As noted earlier, soft launch vs. scale stages have different success
metrics. We will not prematurely force a new market to hit the same
numbers as an established one; instead, we track its progress against
stage-appropriate milestones (e.g., by month 3 post-launch, achieve X%
customer retention and an improving LTV/CAC trend).

Throughout the timeline, we'll maintain a live roadmap of city launches
with key dates and criteria. A sample milestone plan could be:

Q1 2024: Launch in 3 cities (A, B, C). Milestone: Each reaches 5,000
users and \$50k monthly gross revenue within first 3 months.

Q2 2024: Launch in next 5 cities (D, E, F, G, H) using refined playbook.
Milestone: Reduce average customer acquisition cost by 20% versus Q1
launches.

Q3 2024: Pause new launches to consolidate and improve operations if
needed (or continue with next wave if metrics are healthy). Milestone:
Achieve overall LTV/CAC \> 1.5 in at least 5 markets as a signal of
approaching profitability.

End of 2024: 8-10 cities live. Milestone: Prove the model can scale; hit
corporate revenue target of \$X million from new markets.

(The exact numbers and cities are placeholders for planning purposes and
will be adjusted based on real-time feedback and results.) By laying out
a timeline with such milestones, we can track our progress and make
go/no-go decisions for each subsequent wave of expansion. If milestones
are met or exceeded, it's a green light to continue scaling. If we fall
short in a particular city, we will troubleshoot and improve the model
before proceeding further, ensuring we don't expand faster than we can
manage quality and performance.

Section 2.6 --- Success Metrics & Continuous Improvement

To ensure the Go-to-Market and city launch plan stays on track, we will
closely monitor success metrics and institute a cycle of continuous
improvement. Each city launch will be accompanied by a dashboard of KPIs
that measure how well our strategy is working. Key metrics include:

User acquisition metrics: number of sign-ups, activation rate (how many
of those sign-ups become active customers), and growth rate
week-over-week in the early months.

Supply-side metrics: number of service providers/partners onboarded,
their activity levels, and the supply-demand ratio (e.g. are there
enough drivers to fulfill ride requests within target wait times).

Engagement and retention: repeat usage rates, cohort retention of
customers after launch, and customer satisfaction/NPS scores in the new
city.

Unit economics: particularly LTV/CAC (Customer Lifetime Value vs.
Customer Acquisition Cost) in each city. We will track how this ratio
evolves as the city matures -- initially it may be below 1 (as we invest
in growth), but our goal is to drive it above 1 (customers become
profitable) within a defined period. Achieving a healthy LTV/CAC is a
key signal that a city can move from launch phase to growth phase.

These metrics will be reviewed frequently (weekly during the initial
launch period, then monthly as the market stabilizes). If a city is
falling behind on any KPIs, the launch team and central team will
collaborate to diagnose issues and implement fixes. Because we
anticipate variance between cities, we won't rigidly stick to an
expansion plan without adapting. As Instacart's Boston General Manager
noted regarding expansion playbooks: a playbook is extremely useful as a
starting point, but every city is so unique that one must know when to
follow the recipe and when to trust one's taste buds. In that spirit,
our team will constantly question assumptions and adjust our tactics to
local realities. Regular cross-city meetings will be held to share
lessons learned; what we learn in City A's launch will refine how we
approach City B, and so on.

We will maintain a "living" city launch playbook document that is
updated continuously. This is not a static manual, but a collection of
best practices, checklists, and learnings that the launch team can
reference and contribute to. For instance, if a particular marketing
channel (say, college campus outreach) proved highly effective in one
city, we'll note that in the playbook and consider employing it in
similar markets. Conversely, if we discover that a strategy didn't work
in a city, we'll document the context and caution for the future. The
goal is to make each subsequent launch more efficient and successful by
leveraging accumulated knowledge. As one founder described, their
playbook started as lessons from their first market and was "refined
with each city launch\... giving a solid starting point when entering
new markets". Our approach mirrors this philosophy of continuous
improvement.

Finally, success will also be measured at the macro level -- how our
multi-city expansion contributes to the company's overall growth and
market leadership. We expect that by following this GTM and city launch
plan, we will rapidly grow our user base and revenue. The ultimate
validation will be achieving dominant position in key markets. Companies
that executed disciplined expansion strategies have not only scaled to
hundreds of cities but often emerged as the category leaders in every
region they entered. We have the same ambition. By closely tracking our
metrics and iterating on our strategy, we'll ensure that our expansion
is not just rapid, but also sustainable and strategically sound, paving
the way for long-term success.

Addendum A §2 GotoMarket: Studios Launch Scope & Emphasis
(ResearchUpdated)

Goal: Decide how (or if) "Studios" appears at launch without diluting
focus or overcompeting with Peerspace. Preserve our core: talent
discovery & bookings. Use studios as a complementary, lowfriction addon
that increases conversion for shoots---not a coequal vertical on day
one.

A\) Launch Positioning (what "Studios" means at MVP)

Name & framing: "Verified Studios (Lite)" --- curated creative spaces
and private studios suitable for photo/video shoots (not
events/parties).

Role in v1: Complementary to talent bookings. Studios appear as an
attachable option during briefs/checkout and as a subhub under Browse,
not a topnav pillar.

Geographic scope: Founding city only (e.g., Houston), seed 15--30
quality studios max; expand after PMF signals.

B\) Why not a full "Peerspace competitor" at launch

Focus & liquidity: Early marketplaces win by narrowing scope. A full
venue marketplace doubles complexity (supply ops, insurance, deposits,
map/amenity search, etc.).

Differentiation: Our edge is talent + tools (briefs, deliverables,
social metrics). Studios should amplify those flows (shoot readiness),
not become the main show.

Quality \> quantity: A curated set of creativeready spaces beats a thin
longtail that invites comparison to mature incumbents.

C\) What ships for Studios at MVP (scope you can build to)

Surface & discovery

Attach a Studio step in Brief and Checkout (city & date prefilled,
filter by distance/price/amenities).

Browse ▸ Verified Studios (Lite) subhub (not topnav): grid + map,
creative filters (natural light, cyc wall, blackout, ceilings, rates,
capacity).

Studio chips on talent profiles ("Has studio access" or "Owns studio")
when applicable.

Booking model

Instant Book default (host can opt "approval required"). Hourly
pricing + min hours; overtime rules.

Escrow same as talent; damage deposit (card hold) optional per host;
cleaning fee allowed; rules & access shown before pay.

Checkin/out with geofence & door code field; QR access optional later.

Verification (Lite)

Studio Lite (already designed in §3.4): doc OCR + geocode/Place match;
manual exception only.

Required docs: property/space release template + house rules
(autoattached via Smart Docs).

Payments & fees

Same 12% provider / 5% buyer baseline (see §3.1), deposit holds not
counted as GMV.

Refund matrix follows space norms (stricter latecancel terms than
talent; see matrix below).

D\) What we defer (postPMF)

Insurance marketplace, security deposits with offline inspections,
complex tiered amenities pricing, multilisting host dashboards, full
multicity inventory, eventuse cases.

Mapheavy discovery bells/whistles (streetlevel 3D tours, AR
walkthroughs).

Equipment rentals marketplace (separate future track).

E\) Studio Refund & Policy Matrix (v1 defaults; hosts may choose
stricter within bands)

Amenity overages (overtime/crew size): host may file PostBooking
Adjustments within 24h with evidence; buyer has 48h to approve/dispute.

F\) Marketplace Mechanics (how studios add conversion, not complexity)

Brief uplift: when buyer composes a shoot brief, Attach a Studio offers
3 nearby matches with "creative amenities" chips; increases award rate
by reducing buyer friction.

Talent crosssell: photographers who own a studio can toggle Studio AddOn
(hourly) inside their package; the system then exposes that studio at
checkout.

Boards: saved boards can include both talent & studios; Compare view
keeps them separated by type.

G\) Supply Seeding Playbook (first 30--60 days)

Curate 15--30 creative studios (natural light lofts, cyclorama spaces,
warehouse sets) in the founding city.

Fasttrack verification (Lite); waive Studio Lite fee for first 25.

Founding Host perks: Featured placement in Verified Studios (Lite)
carousel for 60 days; 0% buyer fee on first booking to stimulate demand.

Quality bar: professional photos required; template rules; minimum
availability posting (2+ days/week).

Partnerships: local studio associations, photo schools, production
collectives.

H\) Demand GTM Hooks

Bundle messaging: "Book the crew and the space in one place."

Saved Searches: "Talent + Studio in \[City\] this weekend" templates.

Case studies: showcase shoots that used both a Verified Studio and
onplatform talent; highlight time saved.

I\) IA & Nav Guidance (affects §4.0/§4.1 rewrites)

Browse ▸ Verified Studios (Lite) under Browse (not topnav).

Attach a Studio step in Brief/Checkout (primary place most buyers will
encounter studios).

Studio result cards use a distinct badge & amenity chips; but share card
patterns with talent for consistency.

J\) KPIs & KillSwitches (90day postlaunch)

Attachrate: ≥ 20% of shoot briefs add a studio candidate.

Studioinvolved GMV: ≥ 15% of GMV involves a studio by month 3.

Fill rate: ≥ 50% of hosted studio slots receive at least one
inquiry/week.

Incident rate: damage disputes \< 1% of studio bookings.

Killswitch: If attachrate \< 8% and studio search CTR \< 2% for 8
consecutive weeks, hide Studios from Browse and keep only Attach in
Brief/Checkout; revisit supply fit.

K\) Acceptance Criteria (mark Addendum A FINAL)

Attach a Studio step live in Brief and Checkout, prefiltered by
city/date.

Verified Studios (Lite) subhub live under Browse (grid + map); creative
amenity filters.

Studio booking: hourly + min hours, instant book default (host can
require approval), overtime rules, cleaning fee field, rules & access
surfaced prepay.

Deposits: card hold configurable per listing; damage claim flow with 24h
window.

Policies: studio cancel matrix implemented; host cancel strike/IB pause
wired.

Verification Lite flow for studios connected; property/space release
autoattached via Smart Docs.

Crosssell: studio chips on talent profiles when owned/linked; Studio
AddOn in photographer packages.

KPIs dashboards for attachrate, studio GMV share, incident rate;
