§7.7 --- Outsource vs In‑House Matrix (What/When/How to Switch)

§7.7 --- Outsource vs In‑House Matrix (What/When/How to Switch)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on
models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers
and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already
ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with
usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped;
city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups
allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external
deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with
buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional
background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin
tooling and audit trails.

Goals:\
• Buy for commodity lanes; build for differentiation and policy
control.\
• Switch intentionally with dual‑write or shadow modes; cut scope rather
than rush rewrites.\
• Preserve business continuity and analytics parity during transitions.

Why this matters:\
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1--6.
For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and
creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an
execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk
stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:\
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax,
trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical
layer.\
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support
cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.\
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for
higher‑risk launches.\
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and
measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:\
• Decision matrix: payments vs tax vs IDV vs content safety vs social
metrics vs messaging vs deliverables hosting.\
• Techniques: strangler patterns; event shims; gold standard checks.

Processes & cadences:\
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments,
city gating decisions.\
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday
retros; shared ship log.\
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter
policy, money movement, or public content rules.\
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes,
code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:\
• Switch success rate; no analytics drift; limited downtime; cost or
capability gains realized.

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Big‑bang rewrites; frozen features; data loss; unmeasured parity; team
thrash.

Launch checklist (acceptance):\
□ RFC templates; migration checklist; parity dashboards; rollback plans;
success criteria defined upfront.

§7.8 --- Performance, Growth, and Training Ladders

§7.8 --- Performance, Growth, and Training Ladders

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on
models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers
and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already
ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with
usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped;
city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups
allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external
deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with
buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional
background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin
tooling and audit trails.

Goals:\
• Define expectations and growth paths for Eng, Product, Design, Data,
Support, and T&S.\
• Reward outcomes (safe, reversible shipping; measurable marketplace
impact).\
• Make training part of the operating calendar (security, FCRA, tax,
experiments).

Why this matters:\
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1--6.
For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and
creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an
execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk
stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:\
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax,
trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical
layer.\
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support
cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.\
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for
higher‑risk launches.\
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and
measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:\
• Ladders: IC and Manager tracks; examples tied to our surfaces (e.g.,
shipping change‑orders v2 safely).\
• Calibration and promotion committee; peer feedback cadence; mentoring
paths.

Processes & cadences:\
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments,
city gating decisions.\
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday
retros; shared ship log.\
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter
policy, money movement, or public content rules.\
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes,
code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:\
• Internal mobility; promotion rates; training completion; support
handoff quality; incident reduction after training.

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Title inflation; opaque promotions; skill gaps; lack of training
budget; burnout.

Launch checklist (acceptance):\
□ Ladder PDFs; promotion rubric; training calendar; mentoring
assignments; calibration notes archived.

§7.9 --- Compensation Bands & Equity Guidelines (Ranges & Principles)

§7.9 --- Compensation Bands & Equity Guidelines (Ranges & Principles)

Context: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace focused on
models, photographers, videographers, and content creators, with buyers
and studios as complementary roles. The business choices already
ratified are: subscription‑free launch; take‑rate monetization with
usage‑based promotions that are eligibility‑gated and capped;
city‑by‑city go‑to‑market beginning in Houston with nationwide signups
allowed; artistic‑nudity‑only policy for public surfaces; external
deliverables via Drive/Dropbox manifests; daily finance close; ACH with
buyer‑fee discount; Instant Book gated by ID verification; optional
background checks; and feature‑flagged rollouts with strong admin
tooling and audit trails.

Goals:\
• Pay fairly, simply, and predictably; compete for senior builders
without distorting the org.\
• Use national‑US bands; equity refreshes tied to impact; bonus for
on‑call rotations.\
• Document the offer process and negotiation principles to avoid hidden
bias.

Why this matters:\
This sub‑section operationalizes choices we made across Sections 1--6.
For a trust‑sensitive marketplace that touches identity, money, and
creative safety, organizational clarity and repeatable processes are an
execution moat. Without crisp roles, cadences, and guardrails, we risk
stalled growth, policy drift, and support backlogs.

Operating principles:\
• Split teams by value stream (discovery/booking, money/tax,
trust/safety, promotions/growth, studios) rather than by technical
layer.\
• Treat admin and analytics surfaces as first‑class product; if support
cannot resolve an edge case without code, the feature is not done.\
• Ship behind flags; prefer reversible decisions; use city gates for
higher‑risk launches.\
• Everything that touches safety or money produces an audit trail and
measurable outcomes.

Operational themes & responsibilities:\
• Ranges per level/role; equity mix ranges; founder grants policy;
referral bonuses; market review cadence.

Processes & cadences:\
• Weekly business review: KPIs, incidents, error budgets, experiments,
city gating decisions.\
• Squad rituals: daily standups, mid‑week demos behind flags, Friday
retros; shared ship log.\
• Risk review: T&S, Finance, and Legal sign‑off for changes that alter
policy, money movement, or public content rules.\
• Post‑incident reviews: timelines, user impact, root causes,
code/config changes, owner, and follow‑ups.

Success metrics:\
• Offer acceptance rate; regretted attrition; comp‑to‑band variance;
diversity goals met at hiring bands.

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Ad‑hoc exceptions; over‑index on cash; under‑leveled hires; retention
shocks; secrecy around compensation.

Launch checklist (acceptance):\
□ Band tables published; equity and bonus policy docs; annual market
review; refresh policy; exception log.

§8.0 --- Overview & Risk Posture (US‑Only Launch)

§8.0 --- Overview & Risk Posture (US‑Only Launch)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Define our legal and policy posture for a US‑only launch with
city‑by‑city rollout.\
• Codify risk appetites and red lines for content, payments, privacy,
and safety.\
• Make policies actionable with owners, flags, and admin tools.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to all users, providers, buyers, and studios operating on the
platform within the United States. Covers all public content, bookings,
payments, and messaging conducted via the platform or its official
communication channels.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Artistic nudity: non‑sexualized nudity for artistic purposes; explicit
sexual content is prohibited on public surfaces.\
• Instant Book: a booking that can be accepted immediately; available
only to ID‑verified providers.\
• Trusted Pro: an opt‑in background‑checked provider with additional
safety signals and minor fee incentives.\
• Escrow: funds held by the processor until acceptance of deliverables
or completion of studio checkout.\
• Safe‑Mode: default media setting for guests and first‑time viewers;
suppresses sensitive thumbnails.

Policy Statements:\
• US‑only: we contract under US law; we will not knowingly onboard users
domiciled outside the US at launch.\
• Age limitation: the platform is for adults (18+). No minors may create
accounts or appear in content.\
• Artistic‑only public surfaces: explicit sexual content is prohibited
on public search, profile cards, and feeds.\
• Identity diligence: ID verification is required for Instant Book and
recommended for all sellers.\
• Background checks: optional and consent‑based; adverse‑action steps
follow FCRA norms.\
• Payments & escrow: use approved processors; no cash off‑platform
payments are permitted via our UI.\
• Privacy & PII: minimize collected data; mask PII by default; use a
vault for sensitive identifiers.\
• Accessibility & fairness: commit to WCAG 2.1 AA and to
non‑discrimination in access to services.\
• Law enforcement: we respond to valid legal process and emergencies
with audit trails and privacy guards.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Policy change protocol: draft → legal review → feature flag → city
gate → limited launch → measurement → GA.\
• Incident triage: classify by severity (user harm, money, privacy);
invoke on‑call roles and runbooks.\
• Document lifecycle: version external policies; keep internal playbooks
aligned and dated with owners.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Tiered enforcement: warnings, temporary limits, removal of content,
account holds, or permanent disable.\
• Appeals: structured process with timelines; decisions documented;
patterns reviewed for fairness.\
• Chargebacks & disputes: represent with receipts, chats, manifests,
releases; escalate only within policy.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• PII as least‑privilege: mask until unmask reason is given; audit
access; limit retention to business needs.\
• Evidence retention: keep contracts/releases 7 years; keep booking
receipts by finance policy.\
• Data localization: US‑region storage only at launch; reviewed before
any international expansion.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Policy change notice; adverse‑action templates; DMCA intake form;
emergency disclosure checklist; Safe‑Mode rationale; accessibility
statement.\
• Receipt and SOW templates with plain‑English summaries; background
check notices; appeals form.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Safety reports per 1,000 legs; time to first response for safety
tickets; dispute win/loss rate; privacy access ledger reviews;
accessibility audit completion.\
• Quarterly policy review cadence tracked; change log published; on‑call
drill pass rate.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Mismatched policy and product behavior → deploy behind flags with
clear copy to reduce misreads.\
• Over‑collection of data → minimize and vault PII; delete unneeded
fields; mask by default.\
• Unclear content boundaries → publish visual examples; train
moderators; default Safe‑Mode for guests.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ External policy pages reviewed by counsel; admin tools verified;
training materials updated; city gates configured; runbooks tested with
table‑top exercises.

§8.1 --- Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, and Acceptable Use (Key
Clauses)

§8.1 --- Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, and Acceptable Use (Key
Clauses)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Publish clear, coherent, and non‑surprising public policies users can
read and act on.\
• Align the ToS with product realities: escrow, Instant Book, studio
deposits, promotions, and Safe‑Mode.\
• Ensure Privacy Policy and AUP reflect data minimization and
artistic‑only public content.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to every registered and guest user who accesses the site, mobile
pages, or official communication channels. The ToS governs contractual
relationships; the Privacy Policy explains data practices; the AUP sets
behavioral rules.

Definitions (plain language):\
• User Content: media and text a user uploads or posts to the platform.\
• License: limited license users grant to display, host, and transmit
their content for platform features.\
• Escrowed Transaction: a booking where funds are held until completion
conditions are met.\
• Dispute: a disagreement over deliverables, attendance, or rules that
invokes support or chargeback processes.

Policy Statements:\
• Contract formation: ToS acceptance on signup; changes notified;
continued use indicates acceptance.\
• Eligibility: 18+, US resident; no minors in content; no use where
prohibited by law.\
• Fees & payment: buyer service fee, provider fee, taxes, deposits; all
itemized; off‑platform payment encouragement prohibited.\
• Escrow specifics: timing of charges/holds; release triggers;
cancellation and refund math summary; deposits distinct from GMV.\
• Licenses: provider retains IP unless a specific SOW says otherwise;
platform receives a limited license to host/transform content for
features.\
• AUP core rules: no explicit sexual content in public; no harassment,
hate, doxxing, or illegal activity; respect privacy; no dangerous
requests.\
• Safety features: Safe‑Mode defaults; reporting tools; IDV; background
checks; reputation score logic (transparency without revealing raw
signals).\
• DMCA/notice‑and‑takedown: agent info; notice requirements;
counter‑notice path and timeline.\
• Arbitration/class action: optional clause with opt‑out window;
small‑claims carve‑out (to be confirmed with counsel).\
• Disclaimers: we do not employ providers; we facilitate bookings; we
are not liable for off‑platform conduct; limit damages as permitted by
law.\
• Termination: grounds for account limits/closure; appeal process; data
export on closure where feasible.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• ToS update cadence with versioning and redline summaries; banner
notices for material changes.\
• Privacy data maps kept current; DSR (data subject request) intake with
standard verification steps.\
• AUP enforcement queue: content moderator workflow integrated with
Safe‑Mode and strike system.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Graduated responses: content removal, feature restrictions, temporary
holds, permanent disable.\
• Recurring abuse: strike thresholds; Trusted Pro badge revocation;
promotions ineligibility.\
• DMCA compliance: remove on valid notice; restore on counter‑notice
unless suit filed; repeat infringer policy.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• What we collect: account, verification, booking, payment tokens,
device, and limited log data; no unnecessary sensitive categories.\
• How we use data: to provide services, safety, payments, and analytics;
no sale of PII; limited sharing with processors and vendors.\
• Retention: contracts/releases 7 years; booking and finance records per
finance policy; deletion on schedule except legal holds.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• ToS last‑updated banner; privacy data inventory; DMCA agent contact;
AUP visual examples sheet; strike system explanation; arbitration
opt‑out instructions.\
• Email/SMS templates: material change notices; enforcement notices;
DMCA responses.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Policy comprehension (help‑center views, time on page); enforcement
accuracy (appeal upholds); DMCA SLA; DSR response time; privacy access
ledger review rate.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Ambiguous terms → publish examples and FAQs; consult counsel on
arbitration options and state carve‑outs.\
• Over‑reach in licenses → limit to what is necessary to operate the
service; avoid assignment by default.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Counsel review complete; public pages staged; AUP queue live; DMCA
agent set; versioning redlines prepared; strike policy connected to
reputation signals.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake,
escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license,
and moral rights.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid

necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- \'Consider\' background result: pre‑adverse and

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Emergency disclosure request: verification,

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Accessibility complaint: reproductions,

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list

necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- \'Services not rendered\' chargeback: assembling

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list

legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

§8.2 --- Content & Safety Policy (Artistic‑Only Public Surfaces,
Reporting, Moderation)

§8.2 --- Content & Safety Policy (Artistic‑Only Public Surfaces,
Reporting, Moderation)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Define what is allowed on public surfaces and how Safe‑Mode works.\
• Provide clear reporting, review, and appeal paths that respect
creators and protect viewers.\
• Prevent harassment, hate, doxxing, and risky off‑platform
arrangements.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to profiles, search cards, feeds, messaging previews, and any
public‑facing media. Private deliverables may include mature content if
lawful and consented, but they are delivered via external links and not
hosted by us.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Artistic nudity: non‑sexualized displays of the human body used in
creative expression or documentary work.\
• Explicit sexual content: acts, genitals in sexual context, or fetish
material; not permitted on public surfaces.\
• Safe‑Mode: default setting that blurs or hides sensitive thumbnails
for guests and first‑time viewers; toggle for signed‑in adults.\
• Harassment: unwanted conduct that targets a person; includes threats,
sexual harassment, doxxing.\
• Doxxing: publishing private identifying information without consent.

Policy Statements:\
• Public media criteria: allow artistic nudity; disallow explicit sex
acts and fetish content on public pages.\
• Consent requirements: all persons depicted must be 18+; no minors even
in background; creators affirm consent and ownership.\
• No harassment or hate: zero tolerance for threats, slurs, or
dehumanization; removal and sanctions escalate.\
• No illegal content: weapons solicitation, trafficking, drugs, and
fraud are prohibited.\
• Safe‑Mode defaults: guests and first‑time viewers see blurred
sensitive thumbnails; adults can opt in after acknowledgment.\
• NSFW label: creators must self‑label sensitive sets; classifiers add
secondary checks; moderators resolve disputes.\
• Appeals: structured path with second‑level review; examples published
to reduce ambiguity.\
• Location safety: discourage posting precise home addresses; studio
addresses handled via verified studio listings.\
• Messaging protections: rate limits, spam detection, PII redaction
options (support), and report/ block.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Intake → triage → action flow: content reported triggers a queue;
moderators evaluate policy fit; actions applied with templates.\
• Escalation: high‑risk items (potential exploitation, credible threats)
escalate to T&S lead and legal; involve law enforcement where
appropriate.\
• Education loop: add clarifying examples to help center when ambiguity
recurs; tune classifiers to reduce false positives.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Tiered responses: label, blur, age‑gate, remove; repeat violations
escalate to strikes and disable; IB suppression during investigations.\
• Harassment outcomes: blocks, message restrictions, and account holds;
doxxing treated as severe violation.\
• False‑positive safety net: quick appeal channel; restore with apology
copy when moderation erred.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• PII minimization in reports and queues; moderator access restricted
and audited; redaction tools for public pages.\
• Media retention: we store only thumbnails and metadata for moderation;
full files remain in external storage controlled by the creator.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Moderator templates: decision rationales; user copies for
blur/label/remove; appeal receipts; escalation one‑pagers.\
• Safe‑Mode explainer: visual examples; toggle confirmation; guest
banner copy.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Safety reports per 1,000 legs; appeal reversal rates; classifier
precision/recall; IB suppression counts; time‑to‑action SLAs.\
• Harassment recurrence after intervention; user trust scores in
post‑moderation surveys.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Over‑ or under‑moderation → calibrate classifiers; publish examples;
empower appeals.\
• Creator backlash → provide transparent explanations; avoid
condescending tone; keep humans in loop for close calls.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Policy page with examples live; Safe‑Mode default verified; moderation
queues staffed; classifier thresholds tested; appeal paths documented.

§8.3 --- Background Checks & FCRA Compliance (Notices, Adverse Action)

§8.3 --- Background Checks & FCRA Compliance (Notices, Adverse Action)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Offer optional background checks (Trusted Pro) that enhance safety
without becoming a barrier to entry.\
• Implement FCRA‑compliant flows for consent, notices, disputes, and
adverse action.\
• Protect privacy and prevent misuse of background data.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to providers who opt into the Trusted Pro program and to buyers
where a studio or brand requires checks for on‑premise work. Background
checks are not mandatory to browse or book unless specified by a
studio's house rules.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Background Check: a consumer report from a screening vendor provided
with the provider's written authorization.\
• Pre‑Adverse Action Notice: a notice sent when we might take an action
based in whole or part on the report.\
• Adverse Action Notice: a final notice if action is taken (e.g.,
denying Trusted Pro badge).\
• Permissible Purpose: the reason we may request a report (safety for
marketplace participation).

Policy Statements:\
• Consent: explicit, informed, written consent is required; separate
from ToS; withdrawable at any time.\
• Scope: limited to identity verification, criminal records where
lawful, and sex offender registries; no credit checks for creators.\
• Use: report is used solely to grant or deny Trusted Pro; not for
unrelated decisions; no sharing with other users.\
• Adverse action: if considering a negative decision, send pre‑adverse
notice with report copy and rights; wait required period before final
decision.\
• Disputes: if user disputes accuracy, pause action until vendor
resolves; document outcomes; re‑evaluate decision.\
• Data retention: store minimal artifacts; delete per vendor and legal
schedules; restrict admin access with training.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Flow: consent capture → vendor run → results to restricted queue →
decision template (approve/consider/insufficient) → notice steps (if
consider) → final outcome → badge or denial.\
• Training: FCRA basics for Trust admins; scripts for notices; time‑zone
aware waiting periods.\
• Vendor audits: quarterly SLAs, dispute timelines, and data security
attestations.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Outcomes: approve (badge issued), insufficient (ask for resubmission),
pre‑adverse + adverse (with required waits), appeal path if new
information supplied.\
• Misuse: any admin misuse is a severe policy breach; logs reviewed;
employment actions may result.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• PII vault for reports; masked views by default; access logs reviewed;
retention periods enforced; legal hold overrides documented.\
• End‑user privacy: no sharing of report content with other users; we
surface only badge/no‑badge and generic safety copy.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Templates: consent form; pre‑adverse notice; adverse action notice;
dispute intake; approval email; badge explainer.\
• Admin checklists: steps for each outcome; timers for waiting periods;
escalation paths.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Completion time; adverse action accuracy; dispute resolution time;
badge adoption; appeal success rates; access‑log anomalies.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Jurisdictional variation → vendor handles localization; we allow city
gates if requirements differ.\
• Over‑reliance on checks → emphasize that reviews and reputation remain
primary; do not imply \'guarantee\' of safety.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Consent screens tested; vendor contract signed; admin training
completed; notice templates reviewed by counsel; badge logic validated
in search and fees.

§8.4 --- Contracts & IP (SOW, Model Releases, Licensing Tiers)

§8.4 --- Contracts & IP (SOW, Model Releases, Licensing Tiers)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Provide standard templates and a Smart Docs system that aligns
expectations and IP rights before the shoot.\
• Prevent downstream disputes over usage by capturing license scope and
compensation clearly.\
• Respect creators' copyrights while enabling buyers to license what
they need.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to all paid bookings where deliverables or usage rights are
exchanged via the platform. TFP/collaboration bookings may use
lightweight agreements but still require model releases where faces are
identifiable.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Statement of Work (SOW): scope, deliverables, timeline, compensation,
change‑order process.\
• Model Release: consent by a person depicted to use their likeness
under specified terms.\
• License: the permission granted by the rights holder to use content in
defined ways; may be exclusive or nonexclusive.\
• Assignment: transfer of ownership of the IP; rare and requires
explicit agreement and additional compensation.

Policy Statements:\
• Default posture: the creator (photographer/videographer) owns the
copyright; buyers obtain a license selected at checkout.\
• License tiers: social/web; advertising; commercial print; broadcast;
each with territory/duration options and price add‑ons.\
• Model releases: required for identifiable persons; stored with
booking; expiration and revocation terms spelled out.\
• Change orders: add‑on licenses post‑shoot are supported; receipts
amended; SOW updated in Smart Docs.\
• Moral rights: where applicable, we avoid derogatory treatment clauses;
we permit credit removal if safety requires.\
• No hidden assignments: platform license is limited to hosting,
processing, and displaying content for the service.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Pre‑shoot: SOW and release e‑sign; deliverables and license selected;
both parties see plain‑English summaries.\
• Post‑shoot: deliverables manifest posted; acceptance triggers license
effectiveness; upgrades handled via change order.\
• Disputes: receipts, SOW, and releases become the definitive record;
support follows playbook to assess scope.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Breach: failure to deliver or misuse of content triggers remedies
(refunds, takedown, license suspension).\
• Infringement: DMCA process for third‑party claims; internal
investigation where platform features are misused.\
• Bad‑faith buyers/providers: sanctions include loss of Trusted Pro,
promotions eligibility, or account limits.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• Data retention: SOW/releases stored 7 years; hashes captured for
integrity; minimal PII in public artifacts.\
• Privacy: releases and SOW not publicly displayed; only status and
scope summaries shown to the counterparty.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Templates: SOW per role; model release variants; license matrix;
change‑order terms; takedown request forms.\
• Help‑center: \'Which license do I need?\' wizard; examples of common
scenarios.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Dispute rate related to license scope; frequency of change‑order
upgrades; time‑to‑sign for SOW/releases; takedown SLAs.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Ambiguous license language → publish examples; require plain‑English
summaries; prohibit hidden assignments.\
• Edge cases (e.g., collage, AI stylization) → add addenda and clarify
derivative works rights.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Templates reviewed by counsel; Smart Docs integrated; license matrix
priced; support trained on SOW/release evidence handling.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake,

admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid

§8.5 --- Payments, Refunds & Chargebacks (Consumer Law Notes)

§8.5 --- Payments, Refunds & Chargebacks (Consumer Law Notes)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Explain money flows plainly and enforce refund/cancellation windows
consistently.\
• Maximize successful representment in disputes by keeping clean records
(escrow, manifests, timestamps).\
• Avoid unfair practices; provide accessible help‑center content that
sets expectations.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to all escrowed transactions, ACH and card payments, deposits,
cancellations, and post‑booking adjustments within the US.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Escrow: funds held until acceptance; release triggers defined in §1.3
and §4.12.\
• Change Order: a mutually agreed price/time adjustment posted to the
thread; amends receipts and escrow.\
• Chargeback: cardholder disputes a charge with issuer; we respond with
evidence.\
• ACH Return: bank rejects a debit; we handle via returns codes, fees,
and communication.

Policy Statements:\
• Clear disclosures: fees, taxes, deposits, and refund windows displayed
before purchase and in receipts.\
• Refund bands: time‑based buyer refunds; provider‑fault refunds include
buyer fee; late cancels tracked for reputation.\
• Chargeback playbook: gather SOW, releases, chats, acceptance,
manifest; construct a concise narrative; file within deadline.\
• ACH handling: post returns code; adjust buyer fee if method changes;
reattempt under policy.\
• No cash: off‑platform payments are prohibited within the UI; repeated
attempts can throttle messaging.\
• Tips: zero platform fee; optional and processed post‑completion.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Support macros: standard refunds; reschedule; partial refunds;
provider‑fault; chargeback kits.\
• Admin tools: re‑issue receipts; partial refund apportionment; deposit
auth/capture logs for studios.\
• Finance close: daily reconciliation; settlement variance alarms; tax
export by jurisdiction.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Outcomes: refund issued, denied (with rationale), partial; chargeback
won/lost; ACH return resolved.\
• Abuse controls: refund/chargeback abuse flags; repeat offenders lose
Instant Book or are limited.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• Sensitive data: card/ACH tokens only; we never store PANs; PII vaulted
and masked; least‑privilege on admin pages.\
• Retention: receipts kept per finance policy; chargeback evidence
retained for at least 18 months.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Templates: refund confirmations; chargeback narratives; ACH return
explanations; late‑cancel warnings.\
• Help‑center: \'How refunds work,\' \'What happens in a dispute,\'
\'Deposits for studios,\' \'Tips & payouts\'.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Refund SLA; representment win rate; settlement variance; ACH return
rate; average time to resolution; user satisfaction scores for money
tickets.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Ambiguous refund copy → standardize; preview math in price box; reduce
surprises.\
• Evidence gaps → require manifest and acceptance; reduce \'not as
described\' disputes with SOW clarity.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Macros published; finance reports green 14/14 days; chargeback kit
quality audits ≥ 95%; dispute loss rate trending down.

§8.6 --- Sales‑Tax & Marketplace Facilitator Stance (State Matrix; Tax
Engine)

§8.6 --- Sales‑Tax & Marketplace Facilitator Stance (State Matrix; Tax
Engine)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Rely on a tax engine for jurisdiction determination and rate
calculation; avoid hard‑coding volatile rules.\
• Document when we act as collector vs when the provider does, based on
service type and state posture.\
• Ensure receipts and exports itemize tax correctly; support amendments
and refunds.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to taxable services and fees in the United States where state or
local law imposes sales or similar transaction taxes. At launch we rely
on a tax engine configured for US‑only; coverage expands city‑by‑city
per §6.3.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Marketplace facilitator: a platform obligated in some jurisdictions to
collect/ remit tax on third‑party sales.\
• Taxable base: the portion of the transaction subject to tax (service,
fees, deposits if captured).\
• Sourcing: origin‑based vs destination‑based rules for services;
determined by the engine using addresses.

Policy Statements:\
• Engine‑first policy: we use tax provider quotes at checkout and store
a tax transaction id; we do not invent rates.\
• Role mapping: talent services vs studio rentals may be taxed
differently; we configure item categories accordingly.\
• Receipts: show tax lines by leg; deposit auth not taxed; captured
deposits taxed if jurisdiction requires.\
• Refunds & amendments: credit memos issued through the engine; partial
refunds adjust tax proportionally.\
• Allowlist rollout: only enable tax in states we have configured and
tested; show banner where tax is not yet collected.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Admin tax map: city/state allowlist; category mapping; override flags
when the engine is down.\
• Nightly reconciliation: totals by jurisdiction; exception report for
missing tax ids; SLA checks for latency.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Outcomes: tax collected & remitted via engine; tax not applicable; or
pending due to outage (with user banner).\
• Mis‑classification: fix mapping; issue adjustments; document in
reconciliation logs.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• PII minimization: addresses and TINs stored in vault; tax data limited
to what is required; logs scrubbed.\
• Retention: export archives per finance schedule; legal holds paused
when necessary.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Templates: tax‑enabled banner copy; \'tax not collected yet in your
state\' banner; reconciliation playbook; outage copy.\
• Help‑center: \'How taxes work,\' \'Why was tax charged?,\' \'Which
services are taxed?\'

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Tax latency; quote success rate; reconciliation variance; number of
overrides; user contacts about tax confusion.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Volatile rules → centralize in engine; avoid bespoke logic in app;
maintain a small allowlist for coverage.\
• User confusion → show simple copy and itemized receipts; link to help
center; keep support macros ready.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Engine configured; allowlist published; receipts itemize correctly;
nightly reconciliation and exports passing for 30 days.

§8.7 --- Data Protection & PII (Public‑Facing Summary of §5.7)

§8.7 --- Data Protection & PII (Public‑Facing Summary of §5.7)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Explain plainly what data we collect, why, and how we protect it.\
• Honor least‑privilege access, masking, and audit trails for PII.\
• Offer user controls (exports, deletion where applicable) and clear
contact channels.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to all personal data processed in connection with accounts,
bookings, messaging, payments, and safety operations within the United
States.

Definitions (plain language):\
• PII: information that identifies a person (e.g., name, email, phone)
and sensitive identifiers (DOB, TIN).\
• Vault: secure store for sensitive fields; access restricted and
audited.\
• Data Subject Request (DSR): a user request for access, correction, or
deletion of their data where applicable.

Policy Statements:\
• Data minimization: collect only what we need to operate and secure the
service (identity, payments, safety).\
• Purpose limitation: do not repurpose data for unrelated advertising;
usage limited to service operations and safety.\
• Security: encryption in transit and at rest; tokenized payments;
masked PII in admin; JIT elevation for sensitive unmasking.\
• User controls: profile edits; download receipts; data export on
request; account closure flow with data retention explanation.\
• Third parties: share data only with processors and vendors necessary
to deliver the service; contracts require security and privacy
safeguards.\
• Children: 18+ only; remove accounts if discovered to be underage;
report where required.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• DSR flow: intake → verify identity → scope data → fulfill → log;
denial templates for narrow exceptions.\
• Breach response: incident roles; containment; notification thresholds;
post‑mortem with remediation tasks.\
• Access reviews: quarterly RBAC review; remove stale admin accounts;
rotate secrets on schedule.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Enforcement: violations of access policy trigger investigation;
repeated misuse leads to employment action; all actions audited.\
• Appeals: users can escalate DSR outcomes via support; internal privacy
officer reviews edge cases.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• Retention schedule: finance records, releases, and SOW timelines;
purge jobs for expired artifacts; legal hold overrides documented.\
• Transparency: publish privacy summary with last‑updated date; log of
material changes.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Templates: DSR intake; identity verification steps; breach notice
skeleton; privacy summary page; vendor due‑diligence checklist.\
• Training decks: PII handling and phishing drills; admin console
privacy controls primer.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• DSR SLA; time to revoke stale admin access; secrets rotation
adherence; privacy incident count; audit of PII access logs.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Over‑collection → reduce fields and retention; Vault misuse → increase
audits and training; vendor risk → conduct due diligence and monitoring.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Privacy summary published; DSR tooling live; access review calendar
set; breach runbook tested; vendor checklist adopted.

§8.8 --- Subpoena & Law‑Enforcement Process (With §4.14.15 Hooks)

§8.8 --- Subpoena & Law‑Enforcement Process (With §4.14.15 Hooks)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Respond lawfully and narrowly to valid legal process while protecting
user privacy and safety.\
• Provide an emergency disclosure path for imminent harm consistent with
law.\
• Maintain impeccable audit trails and chain‑of‑custody for any data
disclosed.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to all requests from government entities, private litigants, and
law enforcement seeking user data.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Legal Process: a subpoena, court order, or warrant that compels
disclosure of certain records.\
• Emergency Disclosure: a request asserting imminent harm to a person;
processed under a defined policy.\
• Notice: where permitted by law, informing users that their data has
been requested.

Policy Statements:\
• Intake: verify authority, scope, and jurisdiction; reject over‑broad
or improper requests; require correct service.\
• Notice: unless legally barred, inform the user with a copy of the
request and time to object.\
• Narrow tailoring: produce only what is specified; prefer metadata over
content where lawful.\
• Chain of custody: hash and inventory produced files; store in
restricted evidence repository.\
• Emergency requests: accept via official channels; require written
confirmation; log and review post‑hoc.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Admin integration: §4.14.15 legal holds; evidence tagging; restricted
access groups.\
• Escalation: counsel reviews; senior approval for content disclosures;
regular audits of requests.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Enforcement: deny improper requests; seek to quash where appropriate;
document refusals and reasons.\
• Abuse reporting: if a request appears abusive, escalate; do not comply
until clarified.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• PII minimization in productions; redact third‑party PII where not
requested; secure transfer methods; retention per legal hold schedule.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Templates: subpoena intake form; user notice; emergency disclosure
form; production cover letter; denial letter.\
• Logs: request register with dates, types, outcomes; annual
transparency report summary.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Request volume; mean time to legal review; % of requests narrowed;
transparency report cadence.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Improper service → train intake; scope creep → insist on narrow
requests; confidentiality orders → track notice restrictions and expiry.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Counsel on retainer; intake mailbox monitored; evidence repository
configured; transparency report template ready.

§8.9 --- Accessibility & Anti‑Discrimination Commitments

§8.9 --- Accessibility & Anti‑Discrimination Commitments

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Deliver equitable access to the platform and prohibit discrimination
by users in listings and bookings.\
• Commit to WCAG 2.1 AA and continuous accessibility improvement.\
• Protect users from harassment and discriminatory conduct in content
and messages.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to all product surfaces, content, and user interactions.
Providers and buyers must comply with non‑discrimination rules in their
offers and conduct.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Accessibility: making content usable by people with disabilities,
including visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive.\
• Discrimination: unfavorable treatment based on protected classes
(e.g., race, gender, disability, religion, sexual orientation).\
• Accommodation: reasonable modifications to policies and practices
where appropriate.

Policy Statements:\
• WCAG commitment: design system patterns aim for 2.1 AA; audits
scheduled; defects tracked like product bugs.\
• Non‑discrimination: providers may define genre/skill/availability
criteria but may not refuse work based on protected classes.\
• Harassment policy: aligned with §8.2; zero tolerance for slurs,
targeting, or exclusionary conduct.\
• Accommodation: support channels for accessibility needs; studio house
rules must include accessible entry info where applicable.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Accessibility QA: keyboard nav tests, contrast checks, screen reader
flows; bug triage and regression tests.\
• Enforcement: report intake for discrimination; evidence review;
proportionate actions; education first where misunderstanding is likely.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Outcomes: warning, content removal, booking cancellation support, or
account limits; repeat violations escalate.\
• Appeals: allow users to contest decisions; moderators consider context
and cultural sensitivity.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• Data: avoid collecting protected class data unless required for law;
do not use protected attributes in ranking or promotions.\
• Privacy: accommodation requests handled discreetly; limited
visibility; retention minimal.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Templates: accessibility statement; discrimination policy; report
forms; accommodation request flows; guidance for studio accessibility
disclosure.\
• Training: inclusive language for support; accessible design patterns
for product and marketing.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Accessibility defect rate; time to fix high‑severity accessibility
bugs; discrimination report outcomes; user satisfaction among
screen‑reader users.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Token compliance without usability → test with real users; uneven
enforcement → publish examples and decisions to reduce ambiguity.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Statement published; audits scheduled; design system updated; training
completed; report flows live.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Unsafe off‑platform interaction: intake,
escalation, and law‑enforcement coordination.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Model release dispute: reconciling SOW, license,
and moral rights.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- \'Consider\' background result: pre‑adverse and
adverse notices, timing, and dispute pauses.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- DMCA notice: intake, counter‑notice, and repeat
infringer policy.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid

necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Tax quote outage: allowlist fallback and
reconciliation.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Emergency disclosure request: verification,
least disclosure, audit trail.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Accessibility complaint: reproductions,
remediation, and communication cadence.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- Anti‑discrimination report: proportionate
enforcement and appeal paths.\
We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list
admin actions; define audit fields; and annotate guardrails. We avoid
legal conclusions in user‑facing copy and defer to counsel where
necessary, while keeping product/ops steps executable.

Deep Dive: Scenario --- \'Services not rendered\' chargeback: assembling

We capture intake checklists, decision trees, and user messaging; list

§8.10 --- Compliance Calendar (Filings, Policy Reviews, Audits)

§8.10 --- Compliance Calendar (Filings, Policy Reviews, Audits)

Disclaimer: This document is a policy and process blueprint intended for
product and operations planning. It does not constitute legal, tax, or
compliance advice. Consult qualified counsel before publishing external
policies or taking actions that create legal obligations. All examples
are illustrative and may need adaptation for jurisdiction‑specific law.

Context & Alignment: We are launching a US‑only creative marketplace
focused on models, photographers, videographers, and content creators.\
We have chosen a subscription‑free go‑to‑market with monetization via
take‑rate and optional, usage‑based promotions that are
eligibility‑gated and capped.\
Public content is artistic‑nudity‑only; Safe‑Mode defaults for guests
apply. Deliverables are transferred via external storage (Drive/Dropbox)
with immutable manifests.\
Payments flow through card (3DS where required) and ACH (with a
buyer‑fee discount); funds are escrowed and released on acceptance.\
Instant Book is gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in
(Trusted Pro). Feature flags and city gates are used for reversible,
auditable launches.\
Admin consoles enable Support, Trust & Safety, Finance, and Ops to
perform routine tasks without code changes.

Goals:\
• Create a predictable cadence for legal and compliance tasks so nothing
is reactive.\
• Bundle policy reviews with product milestones; keep public pages fresh
and versioned.\
• Audit vendors and internal controls on a regular schedule.

Scope & Applicability:\
Applies to Trust & Safety, Finance, Legal, and Data teams; coordinated
by an owner who maintains the shared calendar.

Definitions (plain language):\
• Quarterly: policy reviews, RBAC access review, vendor SLAs and
security attestations, data retention jobs audit.\
• Monthly: finance close QA, tax reconciliation, promotions
invalid‑click review, privacy access ledger report.\
• Annual: SOC evidence pack progress, pentest, DMCA agent check,
ADA/accessibility review, disaster recovery drill.

Policy Statements:\
• Owners: named DRI for each recurring task; backups assigned;
escalations defined.\
• Artifacts: checklists stored in admin; timestamps captured; outcomes
posted to an internal \'compliance log\'.\
• City‑by‑city: calendar reflects city launches; tasks added as tax,
promotions, and studios enable in new cities.

Procedures & Operational Playbooks:\
• Enforcement: missed tasks trigger escalation; repeat misses lead to
process changes; calendar visible to execs.\
• Risk‑based prioritization: high‑risk tasks take precedence during
incident weeks; low‑risk items may defer with approval.

Enforcement & Remedies:\
• Data hygiene: purge jobs verified; evidence repositories trimmed;
legal holds reviewed and released when resolved.\
• Privacy: DSR volume monitored; training refreshers scheduled; secrets
rotation logged.

Data, Privacy & Retention:\
• Templates: quarterly review checklist; RBAC access review form; vendor
questionnaire; DR drill script; SOC evidence index.\
• Dashboards: compliance status board; upcoming deadlines; error budgets
for misses.

Templates & Required Notices (internal/external):\
• Task completion rate; on‑time rate; audit findings; vendor remediation
rates; incident reduction post‑reviews.

Compliance Metrics & Audits:\
• Calendar sprawl → consolidate and assign DRIs; drift between policy
and product → tie reviews to release trains.\
• Vendor fatigue → rotate deep‑dives; keep a minimal baseline
questionnaire for low‑risk vendors.

Risks & Mitigations:\
• Calendar published; owners and backups named; first cycle completed
with notes; dashboard showing green/yellow/red for each area.

Acceptance Checklist (ready to externalize):\
□ Counsel review completed; public pages staged with versioning.\
□ Admin tools wired (queues, redaction, approvals) with audit trails.\
□ Training delivered to Support/T&S/Finance; templates published.\

Section 9 --- Financial Model & Unit Economics (9.0--9.8)

Generated on 2025-11-04 22:41:06 UTC

Each sub‑section is a detailed write‑up (≥2,500 words) with formulas and
acceptance checklists aligned to Sections 1--8.

§9.0 --- Modeling Assumptions (Traffic, Conversion, City Ramp)

§9.0 --- Modeling Assumptions (Traffic, Conversion, City Ramp)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Establish realistic, testable assumptions for traffic, conversion, and
growth that tie to product flags and city gates.\
• Align finance with measurement: every assumption maps to an event or
metric in §5.\
• Create a baseline and two alt scenarios (conservative/aggressive)
without overfitting early noise.

Key variables & baselines:\
• Cities & cohorts: Houston (Cohort‑1) GA at T+90; City‑2 pilot at
T+180; City‑3 at T+240 under §6.4 readiness.\
• Supply (providers): Active providers = listed + ID‑verified with ≥1
package; Trusted Pro as a subset.\
• Demand (buyers): Active buyers = ≥1 inquiry or booking in trailing 28
days.\
• Conversion: Search→Inquiry (S→I) and Inquiry→Booking (I→B) defined in
§6; rep score & Instant Book shift these.\
• GMV: Gross value of bookings excluding buyer fee and tax; sum of
subtotals per leg.\
• AOV: Average order value per leg; varies by role and city tier.\
• Cancellations: Time‑banded rates; late cancels affect reputation and
rebooking behavior.\
• Chargebacks: Rate on card transactions; ACH has different failure
profile (returns).\
• Payment mix: Card vs ACH share; ACH reduces buyer fee but lowers
processing cost.\
• Promotions adoption: Share of eligible providers purchasing
CPC/Featured; ROAS targets from §3.3.\
• Tax coverage: Allowlist states per §4.12/§6.3; banner when off.\
• Seasonality: Minor seasonality; spikes near holidays and local event
seasons.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• ActiveProviders_t = NewProviders_t + Reactivated_t − Churn_t\
• ActiveBuyers_t = NewBuyers_t + Reactivated_t − Churn_t\
• Inquiries_t = Searches_t × (S→I) × EligibilityRate_t\
• Bookings_t = Inquiries_t × (I→B) × (1 − CancelRate_t)\
• GMV_t = Σ (BookingSubtotal_i) for all completed legs in period t\
• AOV_role,city = GMV_role,city / Bookings_role,city\
• TakeRate_net ≈ (ProviderFee% × GMV) + BuyerFee% × GMV_equiv +
PromotionsRevenue − ProcessorCOGS − VariableOpsCOGS

Cohort maturation curves:\
Supply tends to mature faster than demand in creator marketplaces. We
model a s‑curve for provider activation (profile→IDV→first package→first
booking) and a slightly slower curve for buyer repeat rate. These curves
are parameterized so we can fit them once we have 8--12 weeks of
telemetry.

Eligibility & gating:\
Availability, distance, price fit, and NSFW toggle are filters that
reduce the eligible supply set a buyer sees. Promotions never expand
eligibility; they only surface within matching results.

Data discipline:\
Every assumption above maps to a field or table in the §5 warehouse
(fact_search, fact_inquiry, fact_booking_leg, fact_payment, fact_promo).
Finance does not hard‑code rates; we consume aggregates from Gold tables
with freshness SLOs.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• Search→Inquiry and Inquiry→Booking (city×role) with 7/14/28d trends\
• Active providers and buyers (28d) with growth and churn by cohort\
• GMV, AOV, and leg count by city×role\
• Cancellation and chargeback rates by payment type\
• ACH share of checkouts; promotions adoption and ROAS by role×city

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Early noise overfitting → use ranges and guardrails; wait for stable
cohorts before revising baselines.\
• Mis‑measured eligibility → implement precise denominator definitions
and audits in §5.8.\
• Seasonality misreads → annotate events (festivals, holidays) in a
calendar dimension.

Acceptance checklist:\
□ Assumptions document reviewed monthly; deltas tied to observed
telemetry.\
□ Cohort curves parameterized and ready to fit after 8--12 weeks of
data.\
□ Gold tables for search, inquiry, booking, and payment pass DQ gates.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:\
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand,
apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then
layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per
cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.\
• Unit economics: For a representative \$X booking, compute provider fee
(12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform
net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat
for small (≤\$150), mid (\$300--\$600), and large (\>\$1,000) bookings.\
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid
exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.
Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing
organic relevance.\
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10--40%), chargebacks
(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.1 --- Revenue Drivers (Take‑Rate, Promotions, Other)

§9.1 --- Revenue Drivers (Take‑Rate, Promotions, Other)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Define all revenue streams with formulas that tie to product behavior
and receipts.\
• Make revenue recognition auditable via booking legs, receipts, and
promotions wallet.\
• Avoid vanity revenue---focus on durable drivers aligned with user
value.

Key variables & baselines:\
• Provider fee: 12% of booking subtotal; drops to 10% on portion \>
\$1,000; −1% Instant Book; −0.5% Trusted Pro (floor 9%).\
• Buyer fee: 5% (min \$3); 3% with ACH where enabled; refunded on
provider‑fault cancels.\
• Promotions: Search Boost (CPC) and Featured (weekly flat) usage‑based
with eligibility; clear caps and labels.\
• Tips: 0% platform fee; processed post‑completion (not revenue).\
• Other: None at launch (no subscriptions); potential future add‑ons
deferred to §13.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• Revenue_provider_fees_t = Σ (ProviderFeeRate_i × Subtotal_i) over
completed legs i\
• Revenue_buyer_fees_t = Σ (BuyerFeeRate_i × Subtotal_i) adjusted for
refunds and ACH discount\
• Revenue_promotions_t = CPC_clicks_t × CPC_price_t + Featured_slots_t ×
Weekly_price_t\
• NetRevenue_t = Revenue_provider_fees_t + Revenue_buyer_fees_t +
Revenue_promotions_t − ProcessorCOGS_t − Credits_invalid_clicks_t

Why buyer fee exists:\
Buyer fee offsets processor costs and support while keeping provider
take‑home attractive. The ACH discount aligns incentives by reducing
both processor cost and buyer fee, encouraging low‑cost rails.

Promotions alignment:\
Promotions generate revenue only when providers opt in, and only within
relevance caps. Holdouts quantify incremental GMV so providers spend
when it pays, not because ranking is rigged.

Recognition timing:\
Provider and buyer fees are recognized when the leg completes or is
accepted; promotions revenue is recognized as clicks/impressions
deliver; credits for invalid clicks reduce promotions revenue as
contra‑revenue.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• Take‑rate components: provider vs buyer vs promotions (stacked) by
city×role\
• Promotions adoption, CPC, CTR, ROAS distribution; invalid‑click credit
rate\
• ACH share and its effect on buyer fee and processor COGS\
• Refunded buyer fees due to provider‑fault cancels

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Perception of pay‑to‑win → capped slots, labels, eligibility gates;
transparency in \'Why am I seeing this?\'\
• Buyer fee backlash → clear value copy (escrow, contracts, support) and
ACH discount messaging\
• Revenue leakage via off‑platform payments → in‑chat warnings,
throttles, Trusted Pro incentives

Acceptance checklist:\
□ Revenue lines reconcile to receipts (per leg) and promotions wallet
events.\
□ Invalid‑click credits pipeline operational; audits sampled weekly.\
□ ACH effect on buyer fee and processing cost visible in dashboards.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:\
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand,
apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then
layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per
cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.\
• Unit economics: For a representative \$X booking, compute provider fee
(12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform
net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat
for small (≤\$150), mid (\$300--\$600), and large (\>\$1,000) bookings.\
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid
exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.
Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing
organic relevance.\
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10--40%), chargebacks
(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).
