§9.2 --- COGS (Processing, Trust/Safety, Tax, Deliverables, Comms)

§9.2 --- COGS (Processing, Trust/Safety, Tax, Deliverables, Comms)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Identify all variable costs tied directly to transactions and
exposure.\
• Model processor fees for card vs ACH correctly; capture per‑event
costs (IDV, BG, tax, comms, safety).\
• Keep COGS low without compromising safety or compliance.

Key variables & baselines:\
• Card processing: Assume \~2.9% + \$0.30 per card charge (authorization
and capture as applicable); 3DS where required.\
• ACH processing: Assume \~0.5--0.8% effective with caps; returns
handling cost per event.\
• ID verification: Per‑check cost; subsidized for early cohorts; later
user‑paid or bundled in Trusted Pro pricing.\
• Background checks: Pass‑through or partially subsidized; include
adverse‑action processing overhead.\
• Tax engine: Per transaction quote + monthly minimum;
refunds/amendments charged per credit memo.\
• Content safety: Classifier scans per media; human moderation minutes
for escalations.\
• E‑signature: Per envelope for SOW/releases; negotiated tiers.\
• SMS/email: Per SMS/segment and email send; deliverability monitoring.\
• Chargeback fees: Per dispute fee; lost cases incur processor fees;
representment labor cost.\
• Invalid‑click credits: Reducing promotions revenue; monitoring and
auto‑credit pipeline cost.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• ProcessorCOGS_t = Σ (CardCharges_j × (rate% × amount_j + \$0.30)) + Σ
(ACHDebits_k × (ach_rate% × amount_k))\
• TrustSafetyCOGS_t = IDV_checks × IDV_unit_cost + BG_checks ×
BG_unit_cost + Moderation_minutes × cost_per_min\
• TaxCOGS_t = TaxQuotes × quote_cost + CreditMemos × memo_cost\
• CommsCOGS_t = SMS_segments × sms_cost + Emails × email_cost\
• ChargebackCOGS_t = Disputes × dispute_fee + Losses × lost_rev_effect

External deliverables keep hosting COGS low:\
By using external storage for heavy media, we avoid large variable
storage and egress costs. We still incur classifier and moderation costs
on thumbnails and metadata.

Unit cost levers:\
Negotiating ACH pricing, batching signatures into envelopes, and
training classifiers to reduce human moderation minutes are key levers
on COGS.

Attribution discipline:\
COGS must reconcile with usage events in §5; finance uses event counts ×
unit costs and cross‑checks with vendor invoices and Admin exports.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• COGS % of GMV and % of revenue; processor cost per \$ collected (card
vs ACH)\
• Moderation minutes per 1,000 media items; IDV/BG adoption vs subsidy
spend\
• Tax engine latency and success rate; credit memo accuracy; chargeback
win rate

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Processor fee creep → monitor effective rate; negotiate with volume;
shift mix to ACH where eligible\
• Under‑resourced moderation → safety risk; over‑moderation → creator
churn; balance with training and examples\
• Tax misconfiguration → reconciliation variance; keep allowlist tight
and audited

Acceptance checklist:\
□ COGS model wired to vendor usage; reconciliation report green for 30
days.\
□ ACH return macros and fee handling tested; chargeback kit process
audited.\
□ Content safety staffing plan in place for peak loads.

layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per

exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.

organic relevance.\
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10--40%), chargebacks
(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.3 --- Opex & Headcount Plan (by Phase)

§9.3 --- Opex & Headcount Plan (by Phase)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Plan operating expense and headcount that unlock milestones without
over‑hiring.\
• Tie hiring to GA gates and city expansion; prefer contractors for
commodity tasks early.\
• Keep data/infra spend disciplined (≤15% of GMV).

Key variables & baselines:\
• People: Engineering, Product, Design, Data, SRE, Support, Trust,
Finance, City Ops, Marketing.\
• Vendors: Comms, e‑signature, background/IDV, tax, analytics,
observability, ticketing.\
• Facilities: Remote‑first; optional coworking; travel for city ops and
studio partners.\
• Tooling: Source control, CI/CD, security scans, feature flags,
experimentation, admin console.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• Payroll_t = Σ (FTE_role × fully_loaded_cost_role) + Contractors_t\
• VendorOpex_t = Σ (SaaS_subscriptions) + Minimums (tax, comms) not in
COGS\
• TotalOpex_t = Payroll_t + VendorOpex_t + Facilities_t + Misc_t

Phase‑linked hiring:\
We add squads as §6 milestones unlock: Beta adds Growth/Promotions; GA
adds Money/Tax and Studios; post‑GA adds SRE. Support and T&S ramp with
ticket volume.

Contractor vs FTE:\
Use contractors for non‑differentiated tasks (e.g., help‑center
population, manual reviews) while retaining core differentiation
(search, booking, money, admin) in‑house.

Cost discipline:\
Finance reviews TB/day (data) and compute envelopes (§5.12). Feature
owners are accountable for admin operability to prevent support burden.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• Opex runway in months; burn multiple; payroll % of total opex; vendor
spend vs plan\
• Ticket volume per 1,000 legs; staffing vs SLA; error budget burn vs
engineer operating time

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Hiring ahead of demand → burn increases without revenue; mitigate with
gates\
• Under‑investing in SRE → reliability risk; mitigate with phased
on‑call and drills\
• Vendor sprawl → consolidate; maintain an approved vendor list and
renewal calendar

Acceptance checklist:\
□ Headcount plan per phase approved; offer templates ready; recruiting
funnel metrics live.\
□ Vendor roster with costs and owners published; renewal dates in
calendar.\
□ Runway and burn tracked monthly; alerts when thresholds breached.

§9.4 --- Marketing & CAC (City Seeding vs National)

§9.4 --- Marketing & CAC (City Seeding vs National)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Establish a city‑first marketing plan with measurable CAC and payback
windows.\
• Use incentives (verification subsidies, Boost coupons) instead of
subscriptions to drive quality supply.\
• Balance organic loops (boards, posts, referrals) with targeted paid
tests.

Key variables & baselines:\
• Channels: Creator referrals, studio partners, social ads (limited
tests), content marketing, PR, email sequences, RFP broadcasts.\
• Incentives: IDV subsidies for early providers; Trusted Pro coupon;
buyer fee holidays for first booking in new city.\
• Budget framing: CAC caps relative to LTV; city‑level spend with clear
stop/go criteria.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• CAC_channel = Spend_channel /
NewActiveBuyers_or_Providers_from_channel\
• Payback_months = CAC / MonthlyContributionMargin_per_user\
• LTV_user = Σ (ContributionMargin_t × Retention_t) over horizon H

City‑first tactics:\
Leverage local studios, meetups, and micro‑influencers. Feature local
creators in home carousels. Offer limited buyer‑fee holidays
(time‑boxed) to spur first bookings.

Quality over volume:\
We avoid paying for low‑intent traffic. We favor channels that yield
ID‑verified providers and ready‑to‑book buyers.

Attribution:\
UTM discipline, post‑signup surveys, and blended CAC reporting prevent
false confidence in any one channel.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• CAC by channel; blended CAC; first‑booking rate; time to first
booking; repeat rate at 60/90 days\
• IDV adoption; Trusted Pro share; promotions usage among active
providers

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Vanity signups → require package publishing and first inquiry to count
as activation\
• Over‑spend on paid social → cap tests; demand ≥2× contribution payback
within 9--12 months\
• Referral fraud → limit per‑account rewards; require verified activity

Acceptance checklist:\
□ City marketing brief approved; budget caps and stop‑rules configured.\
□ Referral tracking live; coupon issuance and abuse guards in admin.\
□ Attribution dashboards validated with holdout cells where feasible.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:\
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand,
apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then
layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per
cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.\
• Unit economics: For a representative \$X booking, compute provider fee
(12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform
net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat
for small (≤\$150), mid (\$300--\$600), and large (\>\$1,000) bookings.\
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid
exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.
Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing
organic relevance.\
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10--40%), chargebacks
(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.5 --- 24‑Month P&L Scenarios (Base / Conservative / Aggressive)

§9.5 --- 24‑Month P&L Scenarios (Base / Conservative / Aggressive)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Provide a 24‑month P&L structure with three scenarios tied to city
launches and product milestones.\
• Make it easy to update with real telemetry and to communicate to
stakeholders.\
• Ensure cash planning reflects realistic opex and COGS envelopes.

Key variables & baselines:\
• Horizon: 24 months from launch; quarterly checkpoints for board
updates.\
• Scenarios: Conservative (slower adoption), Base (plan), Aggressive
(faster promos ROI and ACH uptake).\
• City timing: Houston GA by \~Month 6; City‑2 Month 9; City‑3 Month 12
(if §6.4 gates pass).

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• Revenue_t = ProviderFees_t + BuyerFees_t + Promotions_t\
• COGS_t = Processor_t + TrustSafety_t + TaxEngine_t + Comms_t +
Chargeback_t\
• GrossMargin_t = Revenue_t − COGS_t\
• Opex_t = Payroll_t + VendorOpex_t + Facilities_t + Misc_t\
• EBITDA_t = GrossMargin_t − Opex_t\
• Cash_t = Cash\_{t−1} + EBITDA_t − Capex_t

Scenario deltas:\
The aggressive case assumes higher ACH adoption (→ lower processing cost
but slightly lower buyer fee), higher promotions adoption with
sustainable ROAS, and faster IDV/Trusted Pro uptake improving
conversion.

Communication:\
We present scenarios as ranges with narrative drivers rather than
single‑point forecasts. Board updates highlight which drivers moved and
why.

Updating cadence:\
Monthly actuals roll into the model; quarterly we re‑baseline scenario
envelopes to maintain credibility.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• GMV growth by city; take‑rate mix; promotions revenue share; processor
cost as % of collections\
• Gross margin %; opex ratio; EBITDA trajectory; runway months at
current burn

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Optimism bias → keep conservative case plausible and funded; treat
aggressive as upside-only\
• Uncontrolled opex → hiring frozen until milestones; vendor renewals
scrutinized\
• City launch slips → build schedule slack; emphasize quality signals
before spend

Acceptance checklist:\
□ Scenario workbook built with inputs linked to §5 Gold tables.\
□ Quarterly board pack template prepared with red/yellow/green on key
drivers.\
□ Runway calculator validated with cash reconciliation.

§9.6 --- Sensitivity Analysis (Fees, ACH, Promotions, Studios,
Cancellations)

§9.6 --- Sensitivity Analysis (Fees, ACH, Promotions, Studios,
Cancellations)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Quantify how small changes in key inputs move contribution margin and
runway.\
• Prioritize levers that we can influence (ACH adoption, promotions
ROAS, cancellation policy).\
• Expose hidden convexities (e.g., chargebacks) early.

Key variables & baselines:\
• Levers: Provider fee floors; buyer fee ACH discount; promotions
adoption and CPC floors; studio attach; cancellation policy bands.\
• Friction terms: Chargeback rates; dispute win rate; tax engine
latency; moderation load; ACH returns.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• ΔContribution = ∂(Revenue − COGS)/∂x × Δx, evaluated at Base scenario\
• Elasticity_ROAS = ∂GMV_incremental/∂CPC / CPC\
• ACH_effect = (ΔBuyerFee − ΔProcessorCost) at Δ(ACH share)

ACH lever:\
Higher ACH share reduces processor cost and buyer fee revenue; net
effect often positive due to cost savings and buyer conversion lift.

Promotions lever:\
Promotions revenue matters only if ROAS≥2.5× and invalid‑click credits
are low; we control CPC floors and density caps city‑by‑city.

Cancellation policy:\
Tighter late‑cancel penalties reduce waste but may reduce demand;
measure rebooking offsets and reputation effects.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• Tornado chart of contribution drivers; ACH net effect; promotions
incremental GMV; cancellation impact on net revenue\
• Studio attach rate and deposit claim rates; effect on GMV and support
costs

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Over‑tuning to early data → require confidence intervals; avoid noisy
toggling\
• Hidden correlations → run multifactor analyses; keep experiments
orthogonal where possible

Acceptance checklist:\
□ Sensitivity dashboard live; drivers ranked by impact and
controllability.\
□ Levers with high impact assigned owners and experiments.\
□ Guardrails set for fee and CPC floor changes per city.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:\
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand,
apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then
layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per
cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.\
• Unit economics: For a representative \$X booking, compute provider fee
(12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform
net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat
for small (≤\$150), mid (\$300--\$600), and large (\>\$1,000) bookings.\
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid
exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.
Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing
organic relevance.\
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10--40%), chargebacks
(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

§9.7 --- Cash Runway & Milestones (Targets to Unlock Next Raises)

§9.7 --- Cash Runway & Milestones (Targets to Unlock Next Raises)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Ensure 18--24 months of runway with conservative burn; tie hiring and
marketing unlocks to concrete milestones.\
• Define the metrics that unlock seed extension or Series A.\
• Provide a clear \'stop‑spend\' protocol if KPIs regress.

Key variables & baselines:\
• Starting cash: Seed proceeds net of fees; maintain minimum cash
covenant target.\
• Milestones: Beta KPIs (§6.2), GA KPIs (§6.3), City‑3 scale (§6.4),
promotions ROAS, tax coverage states.\
• Buffers: 3‑month buffer for city slips; vendor prepayments under
review.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• Runway_months = Cash / MonthlyBurn (rolling 3‑month average)\
• HiringUnlock = 1 if (GMV growth & conversion KPIs ≥ thresholds) else
0\
• MarketingUnlock = 1 if (CAC_payback ≤ 12 months & ROAS ≥ target) else
0

Unlock criteria:\
We hire ahead only when revenue and trust metrics are sustainably on
track. Promotions GA scales when ROAS holds with caps.

Stop‑spend protocol:\
If two consecutive months miss red‑line KPIs, we pause hiring, reduce
paid marketing, and focus on conversion and trust fixes.

Investor narrative:\
We present a measured plan: city‑by‑city wins, strong NPS among
creators, and usage‑based monetization with fairness guardrails.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• Runway months; burn multiple; EBITDA trend; CAC payback; ROAS; GMV per
active buyer/provider; NPS\
• Trust/share: IDV %, Trusted Pro %, safety reports per 1k legs; payout
latency; chargeback loss rate

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Over‑optimistic hiring → tie to unlock rules; publish \'freeze\'
triggers\
• Unexpected processor fee hikes → multi‑processor readiness; ACH mix
push

Acceptance checklist:\
□ Runway calculator live; unlock/ freeze rules documented; comms plan
for spend changes.\
□ Board dashboard includes red/yellow/green gates on milestones.\
□ Cash reconciliation to bank statements completed monthly.

(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:\
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand,
apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then
layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per
cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.\
• Unit economics: For a representative \$X booking, compute provider fee
(12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform
net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat
for small (≤\$150), mid (\$300--\$600), and large (\>\$1,000) bookings.\
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid
exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.

organic relevance.\

§9.8 --- KPI Dashboard for Board Updates (Definitions & Sources)

§9.8 --- KPI Dashboard for Board Updates (Definitions & Sources)

Financial Modeling Disclaimer: This section provides planning
assumptions, formulas, and structures for internal modeling. It is not a
forecast or financial advice. All sample numbers are illustrative;
replace with real inputs once telemetry in §5 is live.

Context & Alignment: We operate a US‑only creative marketplace
connecting models, photographers, videographers, and content creators
with buyers and studios. Launch strategy is subscription‑free;
monetization is via take‑rate on bookings and usage‑based promotions
(capped, labeled, eligibility‑gated). Public content is artistic‑only;
deliverables use external storage with immutable manifests. Instant Book
requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
ACH reduces buyer fee to 3% where enabled. Feature flags and city gates
control rollout; admin tools and audits turn policy into software.

Goals:\
• Define the board‑level KPIs, their exact formulas, and their data
sources so updates are consistent.\
• Ensure every KPI is explainable and tied to controllable levers.\
• Standardize red/yellow/green thresholds with owners.

Key variables & baselines:\
• KPI families: Liquidity (S→I, I→B), Growth (active buyers/providers),
Economics (GMV, take‑rate, margin), Trust (IDV %, safety), Payments (ACH
share, payout latency), Promotions (adoption, ROAS), Support (FRT,
FRR).\
• Sources: Gold tables from §5.5; event schemas from §5.1; freshness
SLOs from §5.12; admin actions from §4.14.\*.

Core formulas (structure; plug real telemetry later):\
• S→I = Inquiries / Searches (eligible)\
• I→B = Bookings / Inquiries (eligible)\
• GMV = Σ booking subtotals (completed legs)\
• Take‑rate = (ProviderFee + BuyerFee + Promotions − ProcessorCOGS) /
GMV\
• ROAS (promotions) = Incremental GMV × TakeRate / PromotionsSpend\
• CAC_blended = TotalMarketingSpend / NewActiveBuyers (or providers)

Explainability:\
We show source events, denominators, and example calculations. For ROAS,
we use holdout incrementality---not naive last‑touch attribution.

Thresholds:\
Red/yellow/green bands are set from §6 targets. Thresholds are reviewed
quarterly and ratcheted only after sustained performance.

Presentation:\
Board deck uses consistent tiles with spark lines, YoY/period deltas,
and short \'what moved\' memos per owner.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• KPI tile freshness (hours since last update); error budget burn;
number of data quality exceptions\
• Owner list with backups; on‑call data steward for board week

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Metric drift → lock definitions with a ledger; require changelog and
approver for edits\
• Gaming → monitor for anomalies; tie incentives to a basket of KPIs,
not a single metric

Acceptance checklist:\
□ Dashboard ready by T‑5 business days before board; freeze window
enforced.\
□ Single‑page appendix lists formulas and sources; DQ report attached.\
□ Owners sign off on their tiles with short narratives.

Modeling Deep‑Dive:\
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand,
apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then
layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per
cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.\
• Unit economics: For a representative \$X booking, compute provider fee
(12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform
net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat
for small (≤\$150), mid (\$300--\$600), and large (\>\$1,000) bookings.\
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid
exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.
Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing
organic relevance.\
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10--40%), chargebacks
(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Modeling Deep‑Dive:\
• Scenario setup: Define a city cohort with starting supply and demand,
apply search→inquiry and inquiry→booking rates from §6.2/§6.3, then
layer on cancellations, lateness, and chargebacks. Compute GMV per
cohort and pass it through fee structure, taxes, and processor costs.\
• Unit economics: For a representative \$X booking, compute provider fee
(12%), buyer fee (5% or 3% with ACH), and processing cost. Show platform
net before variable ops (content safety scans, IDV/BG subsidies). Repeat
for small (≤\$150), mid (\$300--\$600), and large (\>\$1,000) bookings.\
• Promotions ROI: Using holdouts, estimate incremental GMV from paid
exposure. Attribute revenue to promotions net of invalid‑click credits.
Ensure quality score and eligibility keep paid from cannibalizing
organic relevance.\
• Sensitivity toggles: Vary ACH adoption (10--40%), chargebacks
(0.2--0.6%), cancellations (3--10%), and promotions adoption (5--25%) to
see contribution margin swings.\
• City expansion: Add a second city with a 3--6 month lag. Reuse
maturation curves and observe shared services leverage (support, SRE).

Section 10 --- Launch Playbooks & Checklists (10.0--10.8)

§10.0 --- Alpha → Beta → GA Readiness Checklists

§10.0 --- Alpha → Beta → GA Readiness Checklists

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Gate each phase with objective, measurable criteria that reflect
trust, money, performance, and usability.\
• Prevent premature scaling by requiring admin operability and
auditability before GA.\
• Create clear ownership and escalation across squads for go/no‑go
decisions.

Alpha Exit (internal users + selected creators):\
□ Core loop works: search → inquiry → booking → deliverables manifest →
acceptance → payout queued.\
□ Admin: support can amend receipts, issue partial refunds, and view
audits without engineering help.\
□ Trust: IDV on; Safe‑Mode default; moderation queue staffing plan;
appeals path.\
□ Money: ACH enabled in sandbox; card 3DS tested; buyer fee math and
provider fee discounts validated.\
□ Data: §5 events land in Gold tables; dashboards for S→I, I→B, GMV
live; DQ gates pass.\
□ Docs: help‑center drafts for refunds, Safe‑Mode, deliverables
manifest; support macros.\
□ Flags: list of city gates and blast radii documented; rollback plans
linked.

Beta Entry (Houston public beta):\
□ Invite list seeded: 300--500 verified providers across roles; demand
waitlist activated.\
□ Support staffed for local hours; Trust trained on playbooks; finance
close daily green for 7 days.\
□ Tax engine on for allowlisted Texas rules; receipts itemize taxes
where applicable.\
□ Promotions disabled by default; holdouts and caps configured for later
v1.\
□ Performance SLOs met for search, messaging, checkout; synthetics are
green.

GA Entry (Houston):\
□ KPIs hit: S→I ≥ 20%, I→B ≥ 35%, repeat bookings ≥ 30% at 60 days.\
□ Dispute loss rate ≤ target; payout latency ≤ 48h; moderation SLA met.\
□ Promotions v1 on with caps; ROAS median ≥ 2.5×; invalid‑click credit
\< 7%.\
□ Support SLAs achieved for 30 days; knowledge base completion ≥ 90%.\
□ Incident drill passed: checkout failover, tax outage, and moderation
surge.

Owners & Roles:\
• GM (city) --- owns go/no‑go and stakeholder comms.\
• Product leads --- own feature flags and acceptance criteria.\
• Trust lead --- owns safety SLAs and appeals.\
• Finance lead --- owns daily close, payouts, tax receipts.\
• SRE --- owns SLOs, incident drills, and rollback tests.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• Alpha and Beta dashboards with S→I, I→B, GMV, payout latency, dispute
rates, moderation SLAs.\
• Error budgets per surface (search, messaging, checkout): burn tracked
in weekly business review.\
• Flag registry with owners, blast radii, city gates, and rollback
steps; last‑tested timestamp.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Soft launches slip into GA without readiness → enforce hard gates and
require sign‑off from Trust and Finance.\
• Admin gaps force engineering ops → refuse GA until support can act
without code changes.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ All GA gates green for 14 consecutive days.\
✓ No Sev‑0s in last 14 days; Sev‑1 MTTR within target; drill passed in
last 30 days.\
✓ Help‑center content audited; macros cover top 20 issues.

Scenario Playbook --- Moderation backlog at Beta:\
Trigger: Unreviewed queue \> threshold for \>6 hours\
Response: Enable stricter Safe‑Mode; deploy extra moderators; add queue
limits; tune classifier thresholds.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Return thresholds; publish learnings; adjust appeals
capacity.\
Owner: Trust lead \| Telemetry: queue_length, SLA breach count, appeal
rate \| User Copy: "We're reviewing more submissions than usual. Uploads
remain safe but may take longer to appear."

Scenario Playbook --- Checkout latency spike:\
Trigger: p95 \> target; timeouts increasing\
Response: Scale workers; rate‑limit promos; prioritize ACH calls; turn
off non‑critical services via flags.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Restore gradually; compare error budget burn.\
Owner: SRE \| Telemetry: p95_checkout, error_rate, SLO burn \| User
Copy: "Brief delay processing payments; your card will not be charged
twice."

§10.1 --- City Turn‑Up Runbook (Supply Seeding, Perks, Pricing Floors)

§10.1 --- City Turn‑Up Runbook (Supply Seeding, Perks, Pricing Floors)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Stand up a new city with sufficient verified supply and early demand
to avoid empty results.\
• Deploy time‑boxed perks and CPC floors matched to local liquidity
without rigging ranking.\
• Ship the same playbook predictably: verify, seed, promote, measure,
iterate.

Pre‑turn‑up (T‑30 → T‑7):\
□ Studio partners: 10--20 verified studios; deposit defaults configured;
house rules imported.\
□ Supply: 300+ ID‑verified providers across roles; 50 Trusted Pro;
balanced gender and specialties.\
□ Demand: 1,000+ waitlisted buyers; 50+ brand/agency leads; outreach
sequences prepped.\
□ Pricing floors: local CPC floors for promotions set; featured carousel
plan.\
□ Help content: city‑specific FAQs; local safety resources; studio
access details.

Turn‑up week (T‑7 → T):\
□ Press/PR drop; city landing page live with featured creators/studios.\
□ Founding city perks activated: 0% buyer fee first booking; --2%
provider fee for 60 days.\
□ Referral program switch‑on; invite codes distributed to partner
studios.\
□ Trust staffing extended for local hours; support macros localized.

Post‑turn‑up (T → T+30):\
□ Daily stand‑up with city metrics; tune CPC floors; adjust caps; rotate
Featured slots.\
□ Host creator meetup; collect content for home carousels; capture
testimonials.\
□ Activate RFP broadcast for brands; monitor response quality; adjust
threshold for eligibility.

Owners & Roles:\
• City GM --- owns overall success, partners, PR.\
• Growth lead --- owns perks, floors, featured slots.\
• Trust lead --- owns moderation and safety SLAs in city hours.\
• Support lead --- owns macro correctness and queue staffing.\
• Studios PM --- owns deposit & rules configuration.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• City‑level S→I, I→B, GMV, active providers/buyers; promotions adoption
& ROAS; studio attach rate.\
• Supply heatmap: coverage by neighborhood; search \'no results\' rate;
bounce rate for first‑time visitors.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Thin supply pockets → targeted invites; perks for under‑represented
niches; flexible radius defaults.\
• PR blowback on nudity policy → artistic‑only examples page; Safe‑Mode
defaults; trained press responses.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ Sufficient supply (≥300 ID‑verified) and demand (≥1,000 waitlist) in
place.\
✓ Support and Trust staffing schedules confirmed for local hours.\
✓ Perks, floors, and featured modules toggled and measured with caps.

Scenario Playbook --- Uneven neighborhood coverage:\
Trigger: Searches returning \<10 results in key districts\
Response: Targeted outreach and incentives; Featured rotation weight to
uncovered areas.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Normalize rotation once coverage improves.\
Owner: City GM \| Telemetry: no_results_rate, results_count_by_zip \|
User Copy: "We're expanding coverage in your area---new creators
arriving daily."

Scenario Playbook --- Featured slots underperform:\
Trigger: CTR \< target for 3 days\
Response: Swap creatives (portfolio picks), adjust slot order, test copy
on ribbons.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Restore prior set if CTR worsens.\
Owner: Growth \| Telemetry: featured_impr, featured_ctr,
inquiries_from_featured \| User Copy: N/A (UI visual only)

§10.2 --- Safety & Trust Launch Checklist (IDV/BG Readiness, Moderation
SLAs)

§10.2 --- Safety & Trust Launch Checklist (IDV/BG Readiness, Moderation
SLAs)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Ensure safety systems are ready and staffed before public exposure.\
• Align ID verification, background checks, Safe‑Mode, and moderation to
city‑specific risk patterns.\
• Document adverse‑action and appeals so decisions are consistent and
defensible.

ID Verification (IDV):\
□ Vendor SLA tested; fallback flow documented; fraud heuristics tuned
for local IDs.\
□ Eligibility rules: Instant Book gated by IDV; Verified‑only search
filter returns correct results.\
□ Privacy: PII vault operational; admin masked views; access logs
audited.

Background Checks (Trusted Pro):\
□ Consent screens live; pre‑adverse/adverse templates localized; waiting
periods per FCRA.\
□ Badge logic integrated with search ranking tie‑break and provider fee
nudge (where applicable).\
□ Subsidy program configured for first cohort; budget caps set.

Moderation & Safe‑Mode:\
□ Classifier thresholds tuned; artistic‑only examples published; appeals
workflow tested.\
□ Queue staffing plan with on‑call escalation; SLA dashboards live;
content templates stocked.\
□ Harassment/doXXing macros; emergency law‑enforcement flow rehearsed.

Owners & Roles:\
• Trust lead --- overall safety posture; moderation and appeals.\
• Legal --- FCRA compliance; policy approval.\
• Data --- classifier thresholds; safety telemetry.\
• Support --- macro training; triage playbooks.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• Moderation SLA (time to action), appeal reversal rate, report rate per
1,000 legs, IB suppression count.\
• IDV completion rate; Trusted Pro adoption; safety incidents trend.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Over‑moderation → creator churn; mitigate with clear examples and
appeals.\
• Under‑moderation → safety risk; mitigate with queue staffing and
thresholds.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ Moderation SLA met in dry runs; appeal path validated.\
✓ IDV flows stable; Trusted Pro notices correct; badge logic live.\
✓ Safe‑Mode default for guests verified; examples page published.

Scenario Playbook --- IDV vendor latency:\
Trigger: p95 \> threshold\
Response: Switch to fallback; queue retries; inform users; prioritize
Instant Book candidates.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Return to normal when SLA restored.\
Owner: Trust \| Telemetry: idv_latency, idv_failure_rate \| User Copy:
"Identity checks are taking longer than usual. Your verification will
complete shortly."

Scenario Playbook --- Harassment spike after PR:\
Trigger: Reports \> baseline × 3\
Response: Triage macros; temporary rate limits; visible enforcement on
egregious cases.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Lift limits after sustained normal levels.\
Owner: Trust/Support \| Telemetry: report_rate, action_SLA \| User Copy:
"We're actively addressing increased reports. Thanks for your patience."

§10.3 --- Payments & Tax Go‑Live Checklist (Test Plans & Contingency)

§10.3 --- Payments & Tax Go‑Live Checklist (Test Plans & Contingency)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Prove money moves correctly before opening the floodgates.\
• Keep contingency playbooks for processor or tax engine incidents.\
• Ensure receipts, payouts, and reconciliations are audit‑ready.

Processor Readiness:\
□ Card: auth, capture, partial refund, full refund, dispute webhook; 3DS
challenge test; card update flows.\
□ ACH: link, micro‑deposit fallback, return codes, buyer fee reduction,
retry logic.\
□ Payouts: bank connect, reserve holds, Early Payout per‑use, failed
payout retry.

Tax Engine Readiness:\
□ Quotes by state allowlist; latency SLO met; credit memos for refunds;
outage banner fallback.\
□ Receipts: itemized tax per leg; deposit auth not taxed; captured
deposit taxed as required.

Reconciliation:\
□ Daily close: match processor settlements; promotions wallet charges;
tax exports; variance alarms.\
□ Admin tools: amended receipts; ledger views; chargeback kit templates.

Owners & Roles:\
• Finance lead --- reconciliation and receipts.\
• Payments PM/Eng --- processor integration and webhooks.\
• Tax PM --- engine configuration and allowlists.\
• Support --- money macros; dispute intake.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• Checkout success rate; tax quote success/latency; payout latency;
settlement variance; chargeback win rate.\
• ACH adoption and effect on buyer fee vs processor cost.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Processor outage → ACH/card fallback; queue and retry; disable promos
if needed to protect performance.\
• Tax miscalculation → disable tax in affected state via allowlist;
message users; reconcile nightly.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ 14 consecutive days of green daily close; variance within tolerance.\
✓ End‑to‑end test scenarios pass for both legs (talent and studio when
enabled).\
✓ Chargeback kit demonstrably complete; templates published.

Scenario Playbook --- Tax engine partial outage:\
Trigger: Quote failures \> threshold\
Response: Enable allowlist bypass for affected states; banner copy at
checkout; capture order with pending tax.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑quote and amend receipts post‑outage; notify
users.\
Owner: Tax PM \| Telemetry: tax_quote_latency, tax_quote_error_rate \|
User Copy: "We're calculating taxes after checkout due to a temporary
issue---you'll receive an updated receipt."

Scenario Playbook --- Payout queue stuck:\
Trigger: No payouts \'Sent\' in last 2 hours with pending items\
Response: Pause new payouts; investigate webhook backlog; trigger manual
retries; communicate on payouts page.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Resume queue; audit duplicate guards.\
Owner: Payments Eng \| Telemetry: payout_status_counts, webhook_lag \|
User Copy: "Your payout is delayed while we process a queue issue. No
action is required."

§10.4 --- Support Readiness (Macros, Refund Calculators, SLAs)

§10.4 --- Support Readiness (Macros, Refund Calculators, SLAs)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Equip Support to resolve the majority of issues without engineering.\
• Publish macros, calculators, and knowledge so outcomes are consistent
and fast.\
• Measure and staff to SLAs that match city hours and expected volume.

Tooling & Macros:\
□ Refund calculator integrated; partial and multi‑leg support; time‑band
logic.\
□ Dispute intake wizard; chargeback evidence builder; attachment
checklist.\
□ Moderation escalation buttons; PII redaction; account limits
controls.\
□ DM limits and spam controls; identity re‑verification triggers.

Knowledge Base:\
□ Top 50 issues covered; plain‑English answers; screenshots of admin
steps.\
□ Money articles: refunds, tax, deposits, chargebacks; trust articles:
Safe‑Mode, IDV, BG.\
□ City‑specific FAQs: perks, studios, accessibility info.

Staffing & SLAs:\
□ Queue size forecasts; shifts aligned to city hours; escalation paths
to Trust/Finance.\
□ FRT/FRR targets by priority; on‑call coverage for incidents; training
completion records.

Owners & Roles:\
• Support lead --- macros, staffing, training.\
• Trust liaison --- safety escalations and training.\
• Finance liaison --- money macros and approvals.\
• Product --- admin feature readiness and gaps.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• FRT/FRR; reopen rate; macro usage rate; CSAT; SLA breaches; ticket
categories and trends.\
• Deflection: % resolved via knowledge base before ticket creation.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Under‑tooled support → backlog and inconsistent outcomes; mitigate
with calculators and macros.\
• Over‑escalation → engineer toil; mitigate with clear paths and admin
powers.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ Macros published and versioned; refund calculator validated with
finance; training complete.\
✓ SLAs met during dry run; escalation and paging tested; knowledge base
\>90% coverage of top issues.

Scenario Playbook --- Refund volume spike:\
Trigger: Refund tickets \> baseline × 2\
Response: Enable queue filters; adjust macros; preemptive emails for
known issues; expand staffing windows.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Return to standard macros; retrospective root cause
analysis.\
Owner: Support lead \| Telemetry: refund_ticket_rate, SLA_breaches \|
User Copy: "We've received your refund request and are prioritizing it.
Expect an update soon."

Scenario Playbook --- Spam wave in DMs:\
Trigger: New‑conversation sends with low response rate spike\
Response: Tighten rate limits; require IDV for new outreach; update
abuse heuristics; temporary DM credit freeze.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Gradual relaxation with monitors.\
Owner: Trust liaison \| Telemetry: dm_send_rate, spam_reports \| User
Copy: "We're limiting new messages briefly to reduce spam while
maintaining creator safety."

monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Launch paid visibility without harming search relevance or trust.\
• Prove ROAS with holdouts; keep density and frequency caps enforced.\
• Give providers clear setup, reporting, and refunds for invalid clicks.

Pre‑launch:\
□ Eligibility gates (IDV, Rep ≥ 70, no strikes) enforced; QS formula
tuned; CPC floors by role/city set.\
□ Density caps: ≤2 boosted in top‑20; ≤1 above the fold; frequency caps
per buyer/session/day.\
□ Holdout cells configured (5--10%); dashboards wired; invalid‑click
detection live with auto‑crediting.

Provider UX:\
□ Boost setup wizard; suggested bid range; estimated clicks; QS
improvement checklist.\
□ Reporting: impressions, clicks, CTR, CPC, inquiries, bookings, GMV,
ROAS; alerts for budget depletion and invalid clicks.

QA & Monitoring:\
□ End‑to‑end click tracking; fraud heuristics test; miscategorization
auto‑pause; city ops pricing governance.

Owners & Roles:\
• Growth PM --- product settings and UX.\
• Trust --- eligibility and abuse handling.\
• Finance --- revenue recognition; invalid‑click credits accounting.\
• City Ops --- floors and featured pricing per city.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• CPC, CTR, QS distribution; ROAS median; invalid‑click credit %; buyer
hide/report on promoted cards.\
• Organic search KPIs unaffected: S→I, I→B, satisfaction; measure
cannibalization risk.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Pay‑to‑win perception → strong labeling, relevance match, caps;
eligibility bars.\
• Fraud → auto‑credits; throttle offenders; anomaly alerts; manual
review for patterns.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ Holdout ROAS ≥ 2.5× median; invalid‑click credits \< 7%; organic KPIs
stable within guardrails.\
✓ Provider setup and reporting successful in dry run; billing via wallet
correct.

Scenario Playbook --- Invalid clicks surge:\
Trigger: Invalid rate \> upper bound\
Response: Tighten fraud filters; auto‑credit; temporarily reduce
density; notify affected providers.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Relax once normal; publish learning.\
Owner: Growth/Trust \| Telemetry: invalid_click_rate, ROAS \| User Copy:
"We issued credits for suspicious clicks while we improve
detection---thanks for your patience."

Scenario Playbook --- Provider backlash on labeling:\
Trigger: Feedback cites confusion or distrust\
Response: Improve \'Promoted\' tooltip; publish help page; survey to
validate clarity.\
Roll‑back/Forward: A/B previous label copy if metrics regress.\
Owner: Growth PM \| Telemetry: buyer_hide_rate, help_center_views \|
User Copy: "Promoted results match your filters and are clearly marked
to keep search fair."

• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with

run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause
experiments when guardrails breach.\
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie
metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.6 --- Communications Plan (Email/SMS Sequences, Help Center)

§10.6 --- Communications Plan (Email/SMS Sequences, Help Center)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Coordinate launch communications that set correct expectations, drive
adoption, and reduce support burden.\
• Use lifecycle sequences for providers and buyers tied to real
behaviors.\
• Keep help‑center content synchronized with UI and policy changes.

Provider lifecycle (examples):\
□ Welcome (IDV + how to publish first package).\
□ First inquiry → \'How to convert to booking\' tips.\
□ First booking → \'Deliverables manifest & acceptance\' checklist.\
□ Trusted Pro pass → badge benefits + Boost coupon.\
□ Churn risk → nudge with availability tips and price guidance.

Buyer lifecycle (examples):\
□ Welcome → search tips + Safe‑Mode explainer.\
□ First booking → \'What to expect\' and refund windows; ACH discount
callout.\
□ Post‑booking → review request; referral invite.\
□ RFP broadcasts → \'How to write a brief\' guide.

Help‑center & status updates:\
□ Visual examples for artistic‑only boundaries; Safe‑Mode toggle guide.\
□ Tax and money articles; city perks pages; studio deposit
explanations.\
□ Status page for incidents; templates for banners and in‑app notices.

Owners & Roles:\
• Marketing --- sequences and brand voice.\
• Product --- in‑app copy and help‑center alignment.\
• Support --- macros and FAQ freshness; deflection tracking.\
• Trust --- safety copy and escalation comms.\
• Finance --- money/tax copy accuracy.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• Open/click rates; conversions from emails; deflection %; NPS changes;
complaint rates; unsubscribes.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Over‑emailing → unsubscribes; mitigate with behavior‑based triggers
and caps.\
• Policy confusion → keep examples fresh and visible; avoid legalese.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ All core sequences QA'd; help‑center synchronized with UI; status page
playbooks ready.\
✓ Comms calendar coordinated with city turn‑ups and feature flags.

Scenario Playbook --- Press spike:\
Trigger: Traffic surge and PR mentions\
Response: Pin welcome and safety posts; adjust sequences to onboard
quickly; ensure support has pinned macros.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Return to normal cadence.\
Owner: Marketing/Product \| Telemetry: bounce_rate, activation_rate \|
User Copy: "New here? Start with how booking works in 3 steps."

Scenario Playbook --- Email deliverability dip:\
Trigger: Inbox placement declines\
Response: Warmup IPs; prune lists; adjust sending windows; improve
DKIM/SPF; diversify to in‑app and SMS for critical comms.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Reintroduce segments gradually.\
Owner: Marketing \| Telemetry: bounce/complaint rates \| User Copy: N/A
(backend deliverability)

Implementation Notes:\
• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with
a documented blast radius, an owner, and a rollback plan. City
allowlists prevent accidental national exposure. Admin has kill‑switches
for money and safety features with two‑person approval.\
• Admin Operability: No checklist is \'done\' unless Support can resolve
the top 3 edge cases without engineering and Trust can perform required
actions with an audit trail.\
• Help‑Center Alignment: All user‑facing copy is mirrored in the help
center with last‑updated dates and visual examples. We avoid legal
jargon; we explain outcomes and next steps.\
• QA Strategy: We prefer production‑like staging with seeded data and
synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases
(ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).\
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges
run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause
experiments when guardrails breach.\
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie
metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.7 --- Incident Command & Rollback Drills (Feature‑Flag Recipes)

§10.7 --- Incident Command & Rollback Drills (Feature‑Flag Recipes)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Establish an incident framework with clear roles, SEV levels, and
rollback powers.\
• Practice drills that reflect our highest‑risk surfaces: checkout, tax,
moderation, promotions.\
• Document feature‑flag recipes that safely degrade functionality.

Roles & SEV:\
□ Incident Commander (IC) + Comms + Ops + Eng; SEV‑0/1/2 matrix with
SLAs.\
□ Pager rotations; escalation tree; status page policies; customer comms
templates.

Flag recipes:\
□ Disable promotions; reduce density to zero; keep organic ranking
intact.\
□ Checkout degrade: force card when ACH engine degraded; allow \'pending
tax\' path with banner.\
□ Safe‑Mode hardening: increase thresholds; pause new media ingestion;
keep messaging live.\
□ Admin controls: kill‑switches for money moves require two‑person
approval.

Drills:\
□ Quarterly disaster day with switchbacks; capture MTTA/MTTR;
retrospective with action items.\
□ Vendor outage simulations: processor, tax, IDV; confirm fallbacks.\
□ Data corruption simulation: DQ gates trigger; freeze dashboards;
recover from backups.

Owners & Roles:\
• SRE/Platform --- incident framework and drills.\
• Product leads --- flag recipes and blast radii.\
• Trust/Finance --- guardrails for money/safety degradations.\
• Support --- comms and macros.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• MTTA/MTTR; incidents by SEV; error budget burn; flags toggled; status
page updates; support volume surge and SLA.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Unclear authority in crisis → written runbooks; regular practice.\
• Regression after rollback → smoke tests; post‑incident QA; changelog
discipline.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ At least one multi‑surface drill passed per quarter.\
✓ All flag recipes tested in sandbox and once in production under
controlled conditions.\
✓ Status page and comms templates verified; on‑call schedules posted.

Scenario Playbook --- Processor partial outage:\
Trigger: Spike in card declines; webhook lag\
Response: Prefer ACH; pause promotions; display safe banner; queue
retries; coordinate with processor.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Enable normal flows gradually; audit duplicates.\
Owner: SRE/Payments \| Telemetry: decline_rate, webhook_lag \| User
Copy: "Some card payments are impacted---try ACH or retry shortly."

Scenario Playbook --- Moderation surge from viral post:\
Trigger: Queue length \> threshold\
Response: Tighten Safe‑Mode; pause new media; reassign staff; inform
users.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Reopen after backlog clears.\
Owner: Trust \| Telemetry: queue_length, SLA \| User Copy: "We're
reviewing more uploads than usual; thanks for your patience."

• Flags & City Gates: Every user‑visible change ships behind a flag with

for money and safety features with two‑person approval.\
• Admin Operability: No checklist is \'done\' unless Support can resolve

actions with an audit trail.\

synthetic bookings. We test under simulated load, outage, and edge cases
(ACH returns, 3DS failures, moderation queue spikes).\
• Holdouts & Experiments: Promotions, ranking, and any economic nudges
run with control cells and pre‑registered guardrails. We pause
experiments when guardrails breach.\
• Close‑the‑Loop: Post‑launch, we hold 7/30/90‑day reviews that tie
metrics to actions and retire ineffective steps.

§10.8 --- Post‑Launch Review Template (7/30/90‑Day)

§10.8 --- Post‑Launch Review Template (7/30/90‑Day)

Operational Disclaimer: This playbook bundle is an internal execution
guide. It is not a public policy document. Where compliance or legal
actions are required, consult Section 8 and counsel. Where money flows
change, consult Sections 3 and 4.

Context & Alignment: Our launch approach is city‑by‑city with nationwide
signups allowed, starting in Houston. We launch subscription‑free,
monetize through take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps, and keep public media within an artistic‑only
boundary with Safe‑Mode defaults for guests. Deliverables are handled
via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests. Instant
Book requires ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted
Pro). Payments include card (3DS when required) and ACH (with a reduced
buyer fee). Feature flags and city gates control blast radius, and the
Admin Console enables Support, Trust, Finance, and Ops to act without
code changes.

Goals:\
• Turn launch learnings into process and product improvements quickly.\
• Hold owners accountable for outcomes with clear metrics and action
items.\
• Decide whether to expand to the next city based on evidence.

7‑Day Review:\
□ Adoption: active providers/buyers vs targets; first‑booking rates;
activation funnels.\
□ Trust: report rate; moderation SLA; IDV adoption; early safety
incidents.\
□ Money: checkout success; payout latency; daily close; tax
reconciliation.\
□ Support: FRT/FRR; top tickets; macro gaps.\
□ Promotions (if on): adoption; ROAS; invalid‑click credits.

30‑Day Review:\
□ Conversion: S→I and I→B trends; repeat bookings; cancellations and
reasons.\
□ Economics: take‑rate mix; processor costs; promotions contribution;
COGS vs plan.\
□ Quality: dispute loss rate; review sentiment; reputation score
distribution.\
□ Ops: staffing vs SLA; incident count; flag drift; help‑center
coverage.

90‑Day Review:\
□ Cohort retention curves; contribution margin; CAC payback in city;
referrals and organic loops.\
□ Safety stability; appeals accuracy; Trusted Pro share; studios attach
and deposit claims.\
□ Decision: scale promotions floors? Open nearby city? Adjust perks?

Owners & Roles:\
• City GM --- overall; compile review.\
• Product & Data --- KPIs and analysis.\
• Trust & Support --- safety and ops analysis.\
• Finance --- economics and close; tax reconciliation.\
• Growth --- promotions and CAC payback.

Instrumentation & Readiness Signals:\
• Dashboards per §5; appendix with definitions; DQ report; cohort
charts; incident summaries.

Top Risks & Mitigations:\
• Celebratory bias → insist on counter‑metrics; include \'what went
wrong\' section.\
• Action‑less reviews → require named owners and due dates for every
item.

Acceptance Criteria (Go/No‑Go):\
✓ Action plan approved with owners and deadlines for the next 30 days.\
✓ Decision recorded on city expansion or adjustments to
floors/perks/promotions.\
✓ Review doc archived with links to dashboards, audits, and incident
reports.

Scenario Playbook --- Dispute loss rate out of bounds:\
Trigger: Loss rate \> target for 2 months\
Response: Tighten SOW defaults; improve manifest guidance; enhance
chargeback kits; educate users with comms.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑evaluate after 30 days; iterate solutions.\
Owner: Finance/Product \| Telemetry: dispute_loss_rate, refund_rate \|
User Copy: "We've clarified deliverables and refunds to reduce
misunderstandings."

Scenario Playbook --- Promotions ROAS under target:\
Trigger: ROAS median \< 2.5×\
Response: Adjust QS weights; lower density; improve provider guidance;
test floors; pause low‑quality cohorts.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Restore after lift.\
Owner: Growth \| Telemetry: ROAS_distribution, QS \| User Copy: "Tips to
improve your boost performance are now in your dashboard."

§11.0 --- Risk Taxonomy, Scoring & Governance (Likelihood × Impact, RPN,
Ownership)

§11.0 --- Risk Taxonomy, Scoring & Governance (Likelihood × Impact, RPN,
Ownership)

Risk & Process Disclaimer: This section is an internal risk‑management
blueprint. It does not constitute legal, tax, or security advice.
Coordinate with counsel and security leaders before externalizing any
policy or committing to obligations. All examples are illustrative and
must be adapted to the realities measured in Section 5 dashboards.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace launch; subscription‑free
start; monetization via take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode
defaults for guests. Deliverables are exchanged via external links
(Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrowed payments release on
acceptance. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are
opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags.
Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person
approvals, and full audit trails.

Goals:\
• Create a shared language for risk across product, trust, finance,
legal, and ops.\
• Standardize scoring (likelihood × impact) and prioritization (RPN) to
focus on material risks.\
• Define ownership, cadence, and escalation paths; integrate with flags
and city gates.

Risk statements (top of mind):\
• Mis‑moderation or unclear public‑content boundaries leading to
press/regulatory risk.\
• Payments outage or mis‑settlement leading to user harm and trust
loss.\
• Chargeback/fraud ring increasing losses and throttling growth.\
• PII exposure or vendor breach causing legal and reputational damage.\
• Tax miscollection due to misclassification or engine errors causing
financial exposure.\
• Operational overload (support/trust) at launch reducing quality and
SLAs.

Primary causes & contributing factors:\
• Ambiguous policy or incomplete training; lack of examples in §8.2.\
• Insufficient end‑to‑end money testing; single processor dependency.\
• Weak off‑platform leakage controls; lack of buyer education at
checkout.\
• Over‑privileged admin roles; missing JIT elevation; vendor
misconfigurations.\
• Incorrect item mappings in tax engine; gaps in allowlist rollout.\
• Underestimated volume; insufficient macros; incomplete admin tools.

Leading indicators & early warning signals:\
• Spike in appeals overturning moderation decisions; media mentions with
negative framing.\
• Checkout p95 latency and error spikes; rise in payout \'failed\'
states.\
• Chargeback rate \> baseline; clustering by BIN/issuer or geography.\
• Admin PII unmask spikes; vendor SOC/pentest exceptions; unusual export
volumes.\
• Reconciliation variances by state; tax quote error rates; support
tickets citing tax confusion.\
• SLA breaches in Support/Trust; increased reopen rates; macro usage
slump.

Preventive controls & mitigations:\
• Publish examples and Safe‑Mode defaults; require two‑person review for
edge policies.\
• Multi‑processor readiness; drills; ACH fallback and banners.\
• In‑chat off‑platform warnings; escrow value copy; IB incentives for
verified users.\
• RBAC, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals; vendor due diligence; PII
vault.\
• Tax engine allowlists; nightly reconciliations; receipt itemization
tests.\
• Staffing buffers; calculators/macros; deflection via help‑center;
admin operability gates.

Incident playbooks (summary):\
• Moderation surge → raise Safe‑Mode thresholds; add moderators; publish
guidance.\
• Processor incident → switch rails; queue retries; pause promotions;
status page updates.\
• Fraud ring → tighten DM limits; require IDV; suppress Instant Book;
manual review.\
• PII incident → incident command; containment; counsel; notifications;
post‑mortem.\
• Tax outage → allowlist bypass; pending tax receipts; reconciliation
corrections.\
• Support overload → triage macros; priority queues; temporary hours
extension; surge staffing.

RACI / Owners:\
• Risk DRI (cross‑functional), City GM, Trust Lead, Payments PM, Tax PM,
SRE, Support Lead, Legal.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• Risk Priority Number (RPN) tallied monthly; top‑10 risks reviewed in
exec meeting.\
• Time to mitigation for red risks; number of incidents by SEV; audit
action completion rate.

Thresholds & triggers (Go/No‑Go, rollback, escalation):\
• Any red risk (RPN ≥ 16 on 1--5×1--5 with impact weighted) triggers
weekly review and action plan.\
• Two consecutive months with rising RPN in the same category triggers
board visibility.

Dependencies & assumptions:\
• Section 5 dashboards; Section 8 policies; Section 10 incident drills;
Admin §4.14 tooling.

Acceptance checklist (risk under control when):\
□ Risk register live with owners; reviewed monthly; versioned.\
□ Scoring rubric published; examples for each score; training
completed.\
□ Top‑10 risks have explicit mitigations, flags, and playbooks.

Scenario Deep‑Dive --- Conflicting risk mitigations:\
Context: A mitigation for promotions harms search fairness KPIs.\
Trigger: Organic S→I drops \> 10% after promotions tweak.\
Immediate actions: Revert via flag; expand holdout; convene
cross‑functional review; adjust QS weight.\
Communication: Internal only; no user comms unless visible changes
persist.\
Rollback/Forward: Restore prior QS; publish learnings in registry.\
Owner: Growth + Product \| Telemetry: S→I, buyer hide/report rates, ROAS
\| Evidence: A/B logs; click maps; holdout diffs

Execution Notes:\
• Every risk has a dashboard tile with an owner, a definition of the
denominator, and a weekly narrative. • Risk reviews pair with §10
post‑launch 7/30/90‑day reviews and §8 compliance calendar. • Where a
risk spans multiple squads, the city GM or Risk DRI chairs the review;
actions have due dates. • We prefer reversible changes (flags) and
narrow blast radius (city gates). • We avoid \'security by obscurity\';
we publish clear user guidance, train staff, and keep audit trails for
all sensitive actions. • The risk register itself is versioned; changes
record rationale and observed metrics.

§11.1 --- Product & UX Risks (Adoption, Clarity, Multi‑Role Complexity,
Deliverables)

§11.1 --- Product & UX Risks (Adoption, Clarity, Multi‑Role Complexity,
Deliverables)

Risk & Process Disclaimer: This section is an internal risk‑management
blueprint. It does not constitute legal, tax, or security advice.
Coordinate with counsel and security leaders before externalizing any
policy or committing to obligations. All examples are illustrative and
must be adapted to the realities measured in Section 5 dashboards.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace launch; subscription‑free
start; monetization via take‑rate and usage‑based promotions with strict
eligibility and caps. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode
defaults for guests. Deliverables are exchanged via external links
(Drive/Dropbox) with immutable manifests; escrowed payments release on
acceptance. Instant Book requires ID verification; background checks are
opt‑in (Trusted Pro). Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags.
Admin Console enforces least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person
approvals, and full audit trails.

Goals:\
• Identify user‑experience pitfalls that slow adoption or create
confusion.\
• Ensure multi‑role profiles, search filters, and booking flows remain
clear and fast.\
• Prevent scope creep and feature load that harms initial simplicity.

Risk statements (top of mind):\
• Multi‑role profile confusion causes poor discovery and low
conversion.\
• Over‑complex search overwhelms new buyers; defaults hide relevant
results.\
• Deliverables manifest flow is too heavy, causing drop‑offs and
disputes later.\
• Reschedule/Change Order UX leads to off‑platform renegotiations and
leakage.\
• Boards/following become noisy; feed devolves into spam; DM fatigue
increases.

Primary causes & contributing factors:\
• Insufficient labeling between roles; poor tabbing; mixed reviews
across roles.\
• Too many filters surfaced by default; lack of presets; unclear
tooltips.\
• Manifest requirements unclear; large file flows intimidating; external
links not well explained.\
• Change fees and time bands not visible; provider controls not
transparent.\
• No rate limits; weak relevance; missing foldering and muting controls.

Leading indicators & early warning signals:\
• High bounce on profile tabs; low click‑through to booking from role
pages.\
• Filter usage spikes with declining S→I; help‑center views for \'how to
search\'.\
• Abandoned \'Add deliverables\' step; disputes citing \'not as
described\'.\
• Change orders initiated off‑platform; refund tickets citing
confusion.\
• Hide/mute rates; follow churn; DM response time increases; spam
reports.

Preventive controls & mitigations:\
• Clear role tabs, separate reviews per role, cross‑linking;
role‑specific landing pages.\
• Beginner mode with presets; advanced filter drawer; definitions chips;
engagement sliders.\
• Lightweight manifest defaults + \'external link manifest\' explainer;
examples and templates.\
• Inline price math; protected change order flow; audit trail; lock
messaging until accepted.\
• Foldered follows; rate limits; mute; relevance tuning; \'quality bar\'
for feed posts.

Incident playbooks (summary):\
• Search simplification AB test; remove low‑value filters; increase
presets.\
• Deliverables tutorial video; acceptance window guidance; macro for
\'how manifests work\'.\
• DM spam spike: tighten sends; require IDV for outreach; adjust credits
per §3.2 launch spec.

RACI / Owners:\
• Product (Profiles/Search/Booking), Design, Data, Trust liaison,
Support.

Instrumentation & success metrics:\
• S→I and I→B per role; click‑through from tabs; change order
on‑platform rate vs off‑platform signals.\
• Dispute rate \'not as described\'; manifest completion rate; feed
engagement health.

Thresholds & triggers (Go/No‑Go, rollback, escalation):\
• Drop in S→I \> 10% over 7 days; feed hide rate \> threshold;
off‑platform signals increase.

Dependencies & assumptions:\
• Role‑aware profiles (§1.1), search filters (§1.2), deliverables
(§3.6), messaging (§1.4), analytics (§1.6).

Acceptance checklist (risk under control when):\
□ Role tabs and separate reviews confirmed; presets live; tooltips
tested with users.\
□ Change order UX integrated; macros and help content published;
telemetry validated.

Scenario Deep‑Dive --- Search paralysis:\
Context: Buyers apply too many filters, zero results.\
Trigger: No‑results rate up in key cohorts.\
Immediate actions: Suggest relaxations; show \'near matches\'; auto‑save
boards for later.\
Communication: In‑UI nudges; help article link.\
Rollback/Forward: Restore stricter defaults if irrelevant results rise.\
Owner: Search PM \| Telemetry: no_results_rate, CTR \| Evidence: Filter
combinations; session replays (privacy‑safe)
