§13.2 --- Identity Verification, Background Checks & E‑Signature
Partners

§13.2 --- Identity Verification, Background Checks & E‑Signature
Partners

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for
partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create
commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy
policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal
review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free;
monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based
promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for
guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with
immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is
gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces
least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits,
and kill‑switches.

Goals:\
• Increase Instant Book eligibility safely with high IDV completion and
optional BG checks; reduce dispute and safety incidents.\
• Enable compliant e‑signature for SOW/releases without leaving the
platform.

Target partner segments:\
• IDV providers (document + selfie checks); BG providers with FCRA
workflows; e‑signature vendors with embedded flows.

Mutual value proposition:\
• Trust lift → higher conversion; fewer impersonation scams; easier
dispute resolution with verified identity.\
• Seamless SOW/releases reduce friction and create better evidence for
chargebacks.

Selection criteria & due diligence:\
• Accuracy/latency; liveness detection; edge case coverage (lighting,
IDs); re‑verification options.\
• FCRA compliance (pre‑adverse/adverse notices); adjudication portal;
dispute handling; audit logs.\
• Signature templates, API, webhook receipts, long‑term storage, and
hash verification.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):\
• IDV modal, consent screens, retry flows; badges; \'verified‑only\'
search filter.\
• BG consent; status messaging; Trusted Pro badge; reputation
integration.\
• E‑signature templates (SOW, releases), per‑booking envelopes; receipts
linkback.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):\
• Per‑check pricing with volume tiers; subsidies for founding city;
credits on false positives.\
• E‑signature per‑envelope or monthly pool; usage alerts.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):\
• Help‑center copy; sample SOW/release library; appeals instructions;
adverse action templates.\
• Macros for edge cases (name mismatches; re‑verification; BG disputes).

Top risks & mitigations:\
• False declines; user frustration; FCRA errors; cost overrun from high
retry rates.

Operational playbooks (summary):\
• Switch to lighter IDV threshold for non‑Instant Book use; maintain
stricter bar for IB.\
• Pause BG adjudication if legal notices misconfigured; fix templates;
resume.

Owners & RACI:\
• Trust lead, Legal, Product (Trust), Support, Data.

KPIs & leading indicators:\
• IDV completion; IB adoption; BG pass rate; adverse action timing
adherence; dispute rate changes.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):\
✓ IDV and BG flows pass QA; legal templates reviewed; badges gated;
audit logs live; appeals working.

Timeline & checkpoints:\
• IDV in Beta; BG rollout optional post‑beta; e‑signature in GA.

Scenario Playbook --- IDV false‑positive cluster:\
Trigger: Completion drops; reports by specific device/OS\
Response: Vendor escalation; adjust thresholds; publish guidance; extend
retries.\
Legal/Comms: UI hints; support macro; status page if widespread.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Revert threshold; schedule root‑cause review.\
Owner: Trust/Product \| Telemetry: idv_completion, retry_rate \|
Evidence: Vendor logs, device/OS breakdown

§13.3 --- Studios & Locations Ecosystem (Verification, House Rules,
Deposits)

§13.3 --- Studios & Locations Ecosystem (Verification, House Rules,
Deposits)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for
partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create
commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy
policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal
review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free;
monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based
promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for
guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with
immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is
gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces
least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits,
and kill‑switches.

Goals:\
• Create a curated network of verified studios and locations that
improve shoot safety and convenience.\
• Pilot studio features in a narrow cohort before broader expansion.

Target partner segments:\
• Photography/video studios, co‑working creative spaces, community
college studios, reputable independent owners.

Mutual value proposition:\
• Easier location logistics; safer venues; cross‑promotion; bundled
offers with creators.\
• Studios gain inbound bookings from our buyer base; we gain supply and
co‑marketing.

Selection criteria & due diligence:\
• Legitimate business presence (docs), safety features (access control),
clear house rules, insurance.\
• Responsiveness to verification and policy alignment.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):\
• Studio verification flow; badge; search filter; house rules; deposit
defaults; check‑in/out.\
• Studio calendar sync; host messaging; incident reporting; deposit
capture/void; receipts.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):\
• Standard take‑rate on studio leg when LBG later; initial pilot with
flat fees or rev‑share; deposit mechanics with no platform fee on
deposit capture.\
• Co‑marketing swaps; featuring in city carousels; referral programs.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):\
• Studio onboarding kit; sample house rules; safety signage templates;
deposit FAQ.\
• Partner meetups; photo/video collateral for carousels; studio‑backed
creator promo days.

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Deposit disputes; misaligned rules; safety incidents; host no‑shows;
double bookings.

Operational playbooks (summary):\
• Deposit claim review; evidence list; capture/partial capture rules;
appeals.\
• Host support: no‑show resolution, refunds, and rescheduling guidance.

Owners & RACI:\
• Studios PM, City Ops, Trust, Support, Finance.

KPIs & leading indicators:\
• Studio attach rate; dispute rate; deposit claim frequency and
outcomes; host/buyer NPS; repeat rate.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):\
✓ 10--20 verified studios per city; rules and deposit defaults tested;
dispute kit functioning; SLAs stable.

Timeline & checkpoints:\
• Pilot in Houston at or after GA; expand to Dallas/Austin
post‑learners.

Scenario Playbook --- Deposit claim spike:\
Trigger: Claims \> threshold in a week\
Response: Audit evidence; coach hosts; tune defaults; improve
pre‑booking disclosures.\
Legal/Comms: Help updates; targeted emails to frequent claimants.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Lower deposit amounts temporarily; increase
education.\
Owner: Studios PM/Support \| Telemetry: deposit_claim_rate,
claim_outcomes \| Evidence: Photos, timestamps, chat logs

Implementation Notes:\
• Partner Governance: Maintain a single source of truth for partner
status (prospect, NDA, pilot, GA), contacts, contracts, scopes, and
SLAs. Tag all features behind partner flags and city gates to avoid
blast‑radius mistakes. • Privacy & Data: Apply least‑data
principles---only request scopes needed for the user value; rotate
tokens; revoke access on inactivity. • Security & Audits: Vendor
SOC/pentest reports stored with expiry reminders; incident bridges
pre‑arranged for Sev‑1/Sev‑0. • Co‑Marketing Discipline: Announce after
pilots prove value; enforce clear success metrics; align PR/brand tone
with our artistic‑only policy. • Support & Playbooks: Create
partner‑specific macros; train Support/Trust on integration quirks; log
incidents with partner tags. • Measurement: Attribute partner impact in

provider, studio attach from verified partners). • Contracts: Avoid

§13.4 --- Brand & Agency Partnerships (RFPs, Preferred Vendors, Case
Studies)

§13.4 --- Brand & Agency Partnerships (RFPs, Preferred Vendors, Case
Studies)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for
partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create
commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy
policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal
review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free;
monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based
promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for
guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with
immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is
gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces
least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits,
and kill‑switches.

Goals:\
• Attract repeat buyers with RFP tools and preferred vendor lists.\
• Lower CAC via partner co‑marketing and showcase case studies.

Target partner segments:\
• SMBs with recurring content needs; agencies; DTC brands; local
businesses; hospitality and real estate marketers.

Mutual value proposition:\
• Brands: curated supply, RFP broadcast, escrow, tax receipts, cost
centers, team notes.\
• Our platform: steady demand, higher GMV, co‑marketing reach, city
credibility.

Selection criteria & due diligence:\
• Budget fit; creative categories; SLA expectations; legal/brand safety
requirements.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):\
• RFP creation and broadcast; preferred vendor folders; invoice/PO
flows; cost centers; API hooks later.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):\
• No subscription at launch; usage‑based RFP credits; potential volume
credits; co‑marketing exchanges.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):\

Owners & RACI:\
• Brand Partnerships lead, Growth, Support/AM, Legal.

KPIs & leading indicators:\
• RFP volume; response quality/time; conversion rate; repeat spend;

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):\
✓ 3--5 anchor brands per city; RFP pipeline healthy; conversion ≥
targets; co‑marketing content live.

Timeline & checkpoints:\
• Begin in Beta with 2--3 brands; expand post‑GA; formalize AM tiering
later.

§13.5 --- Social Platform & Analytics Partners (IG/YT/TT/X/LinkedIn +
Analytics Providers)

§13.5 --- Social Platform & Analytics Partners (IG/YT/TT/X/LinkedIn +
Analytics Providers)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for
partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create
commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy
policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal
review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free;
monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based
promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for
guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with
immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is
gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces
least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits,
and kill‑switches.

Goals:\
• Power verified social metrics, engagement filters, and growth trends
with official connections and compliant scopes.\
• Phase integration by feasibility and partner access, keeping link‑only
options where APIs are closed.

Target partner segments:\
• Instagram/Meta for verified metrics; YouTube/Google; TikTok; X
(Twitter); LinkedIn (Pages or partner access).\
• Third‑party analytics providers with compliant aggregation; link‑only
for others.

Mutual value proposition:\
• Buyers get confidence in reach/engagement; providers differentiate
with verified chips.\
• Platform gains unique discovery features and reasons to connect
accounts (stickiness).

Selection criteria & due diligence:\
• API scope minimalism; rate limits; clear policy; compliance with
platform terms; branding rules.\
• Ability to refresh nightly + manual refresh; fair use and quotas;
stability history.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):\
• OAuth connects; fetch followers, ER, avg views; show verified chips;
trend sparklines.\
• Advanced metrics (phase 2) for connected accounts only; public
discovery within policy bounds.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):\
• Typically no direct fees; rate‑limit & review constraints; potential
partner programs; compliance costs internal.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):\
• Clear \'why connect\' copy; low‑friction OAuth; privacy info;
disconnect/self‑report options; verified‑only search toggle.

Top risks & mitigations:\
• API access changes; policy violations; misinterpretation of metrics;
rate‑limit induced outages.

Operational playbooks (summary):\
• Graceful degradation to self‑reported with \'unverified\' label; cache
and backoff; communicate transparently.

Owners & RACI:\
• Search/Data PMs; Legal; Security; Marketing for co‑marketing
approvals.

KPIs & leading indicators:\
• Connect rates; query usage for social filters; bookings uplift;
refresh success; support tickets on metrics.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):\
✓ Verified chips working; nightly refresh within quotas; help content
clear; no policy violations.

Timeline & checkpoints:\
• Day‑1 IG/YT/TT/X; Phase‑2 LinkedIn if partner access; continuous
compliance reviews.

Scenario Playbook --- API quota exhaustion:\
Trigger: Refresh jobs fail due to rate limits\
Response: Backoff; prioritize top accounts; expose manual refresh
limits; show stale data banner.\
Legal/Comms: Help‑center notice; in‑product tooltip.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑enable normal cadence after quota reset.\
Owner: Data/Search \| Telemetry: refresh_success, quota_usage \|
Evidence: Job logs; API responses

§13.6 --- Education & Community Partners (Universities, Trade Schools,
Creator Clubs)

§13.6 --- Education & Community Partners (Universities, Trade Schools,
Creator Clubs)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for
partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create
commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy
policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal
review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free;
monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based
promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for
guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with
immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is
gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces
least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits,
and kill‑switches.

Goals:\
• Seed supply and cultivate best practices via education channels that
replenish the marketplace.\
• Offer safety training, portfolio reviews, and city meetups that build
trust and loyalty.

Target partner segments:\
• University photo/video programs; community colleges; trade schools;
creator clubs; camera stores; meetup groups.

Mutual value proposition:\
• Students and emerging creators get paid experience and safety
scaffolds; schools get career outcomes.\
• We gain verified, trained supply and grassroots co‑marketing.

Selection criteria & due diligence:\
• Program legitimacy; faculty champions; safety posture; willingness to
co‑host trainings and meetups.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):\
• Campus workshops: Safe‑Mode, deliverables manifest, contracts,
reputation; co‑hosted creator days in partner studios.\
• Referral codes; verified badges for program participants (non‑monetary
recognition).

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):\
• Non‑financial in most cases; mutual promotion; event co‑sponsorship;
limited grants for founding programs.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):\
• Campus starter kit; deck and curriculum; checklist for faculty; event
playbook; creator ambassador program.

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Overhead vs. ROI; policy misunderstandings; reputational risk if
program faces controversy.

Operational playbooks (summary):\
• Pilot small; measure outcomes; keep content apolitical; focus on craft
and safety; pause if controversy arises.

Owners & RACI:\
• Community lead, City Ops, Trust, Marketing.

KPIs & leading indicators:\
• Signups and activation from partner programs; time‑to‑first booking;
retention; safety incident rates among cohorts.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):\
✓ At least 2 partner programs per city; workshops delivered; measurable
activation and safety improvements.

Timeline & checkpoints:\
• Begin in Houston beta; expand to Dallas/Austin; annual refresh of
materials.

Scenario Playbook --- Low activation from partner school:\
Trigger: Few bookings post‑workshop\
Response: Follow‑up coaching; pairing with studios; featured carousel
for graduates; refine curriculum.\
Legal/Comms: Newsletter spotlight; mentor program invitations.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Scale back if outcomes remain weak.\
Owner: Community lead \| Telemetry: activation_rate,
time_to_first_booking \| Evidence: Attendance, portfolio quality reviews

§13.7 --- API & Integration Partners (Zapier, Slack, Drive/Dropbox,
Calendar, CRM)

§13.7 --- API & Integration Partners (Zapier, Slack, Drive/Dropbox,
Calendar, CRM)

Partnerships Disclaimer: This is an internal planning document for
partner strategy and ecosystem development. It does not create
commitments. All integrations ship behind flags, follow privacy
policies, and require vendor due diligence, DPAs, SLAs, and legal
review. Commercial terms are illustrative until negotiated.

Context & Alignment: US‑only marketplace at launch; subscription‑free;
monetization via take‑rate and capped, eligibility‑gated usage‑based
promotions. Public content is artistic‑only with Safe‑Mode on for
guests. Deliverables flow via external links (Drive/Dropbox) with
immutable manifests; escrow releases on acceptance. Instant Book is
gated by ID verification; background checks are opt‑in (Trusted Pro).
Rollouts are city‑gated behind feature flags; Admin Console enforces
least‑privilege, JIT elevation, two‑person approvals, immutable audits,
and kill‑switches.

Goals:\
• Let power users connect our marketplace to their workflows without
compromising safety or fairness.\
• Start with read‑oriented, narrow scopes; expand only after abuse and
privacy reviews.

Target partner segments:\
• Zapier/IFTTT; Slack/MS Teams; Google Drive/Dropbox;
Google/Apple/Outlook Calendar; Notion/Airtable; Mailchimp/HubSpot for
brands.

Mutual value proposition:\
• Automations reduce admin toil (e.g., copy bookings to calendar, notify
teams, archive deliverables manifests).\
• Brands integrate with their CRMs; providers streamline follow‑ups and
reviews.

Selection criteria & due diligence:\
• OAuth scopes; per‑event webhooks; rate limits; strong ecosystem docs;
permissioning and audit logs.

Integration scopes & surfaces (what we build):\
• Outbound webhooks for booking events; calendar sync; file manifest
export; Slack notifications; RFP broadcast hooks.\
• Inbound limited (e.g., RFP create from a brand system) with strict
validation and rate limits.

Commercial & legal patterns (illustrative):\
• Most APIs free to integrate; paid plans for high call volumes; partner
directories for co‑listing.

Enablement & co‑marketing (how we launch together):\
• Developer portal (later); sample zaps; Slack app with scoped
permissions; step‑by‑step guides; support forum.

Top risks & mitigations:\
• Abuse via automations (spam); privacy leaks via over‑broad scopes;
rate‑limit exhaustion; shadow workflows creating support burden.

Operational playbooks (summary):\
• Throttle; per‑user caps; approval for certain zaps; audit logs;
automated abuse detection; revoke tokens on violations.

Owners & RACI:\
• Platform PM/Eng, Security, Data, Support.

KPIs & leading indicators:\
• Integration adoption; errors; rate‑limit hits; support tickets;
bookings attributed to integrations.

Acceptance criteria (ready / successful when):\
✓ Zaps and Slack app pass security review; scopes minimal; abuse anomaly
rates low; docs published.

Timeline & checkpoints:\
• Post multi‑city GA; staged allowlists; developer portal beta later.

Scenario Playbook --- Slack app spam:\
Trigger: Automated DMs create spam complaints\
Response: Disable outbound DM event; require manual approval; limit to
channels; add rate caps.\
Legal/Comms: Changelog and help‑center updates; outreach to affected
users.\
Roll‑back/Forward: Re‑enable with stricter scopes after mitigation.\
Owner: Platform PM/Security \| Telemetry: spam_reports, rate_limit_hits
\| Evidence: Webhook logs; Slack audit logs

# Appendices A--G

*--- Begin: Appendices_A_to_G_Combined_v2.docx ---*

Appendix A --- Glossary & Role Map

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose\
This appendix standardizes the language and responsibilities used across
the plan. It prevents ambiguity across product, engineering, trust &
safety, support, finance, legal, data, and city ops. It aligns directly
with Sections 1 (UX), 3 (Monetization), 4 (Architecture), 5 (Data), 8
(Policies), 10 (Launch), 11 (Risk), and 12 (Roadmap).

A1. Core Marketplace Terms (Plain‑English)

• \*\*Buyer\*\* --- The party paying for a service (e.g., photographer
hiring a model, brand hiring a creator, or buyer booking a studio in
later phases). May be an individual or a business/brand account.

• \*\*Provider / Seller / Talent\*\* --- A user offering services
(model, photographer, videographer, content creator). A single person
can hold multiple roles.

• \*\*Studio Host\*\* --- A business or individual offering a physical
studio/location for shoots (phase‑gated).

• \*\*Service Profile\*\* --- A role‑specific profile (e.g., \'Model\',
\'Photographer\') under one account, each with its own packages,
availability, reviews, and pricing.

• \*\*Package\*\* --- A priced bundle (time, scope, deliverables) a
provider offers. Buyers can add extras and licensing.

• \*\*Instant Book\*\* --- Booking flow that does not require explicit
provider approval. Requires ID Verification; can be toggled by the
provider.

• \*\*Escrow\*\* --- Funds held by the platform until
completion/acceptance; reduces fraud and enables dispute resolution.

• \*\*Change Order\*\* --- A post‑acceptance modification to
date/time/scope/price, proposed by either party and accepted by the
other.

• \*\*Deliverables Manifest\*\* --- A structured list of items the
provider commits to deliver (files, counts, formats). We store an
immutable external‑link manifest for evidence.

• \*\*Acceptance Window\*\* --- Time after deliverables are posted for
the buyer to accept or raise issues before escrow releases
automatically.

• \*\*LBG (Linked Booking Group)\*\* --- A multi‑leg booking (e.g.,
talent + studio) paid as one transaction with separate receipts.
Phase‑gated.

• \*\*Reputation Score\*\* --- A 0--100 score derived from reviews,
reliability, responsiveness, verifications, and recent performance
(role‑aware, time‑weighted).

• \*\*Verified/Trusted Pro\*\* --- Badges for ID‑verified users and
background‑checked users, respectively.

• \*\*Promoted / Boosted\*\* --- Paid visibility units (capped, labeled,
eligibility‑gated). Never override relevance.

• \*\*Safe‑Mode\*\* --- Default public content filter for guests. Public
surfaces allow only artistic‑grade content; explicit sexual content is
disallowed.

• \*\*Boards\*\* --- Buyer's saved shortlists of providers for a
project. Board sponsor (later) is a paid placement product.

• \*\*RFP\*\* --- Request For Proposal---buyer broadcasts a brief to
vetted providers meeting filters.

• \*\*Dispute\*\* --- Formal resolution process when either party
contests delivery, timeliness, or policy violations.

• \*\*Support Case\*\* --- Ticket in the admin console tying user
reports, refunds, and moderation actions to a single timeline.

• \*\*City Gate / Allowlist\*\* --- Feature flag and supply gating per
city to ensure measured rollouts and reversible changes.

A2. Role Map (RACI)

Roles: Buyer/Brand; Provider (Model/Photographer/Videographer/Creator);
Studio Host; Support; Trust & Safety; Finance; Tax; Payments; City GM;
Growth/Promotions; Product; SRE/Security; Legal; Data.\
For each core workflow (search, booking, change order, deliverables,
acceptance, dispute, payout, promotions, verification), this map
clarifies who is Responsible (doing), Accountable (owning outcome),
Consulted (providing input), and Informed (kept aware).

• \*\*Search & Discovery\*\* --- Responsible: Product/Search;
Accountable: Product; Consulted: Data, Trust; Informed: Support, City
Ops

• \*\*Booking & Escrow\*\* --- Responsible: Product/Payments;
Accountable: Product; Consulted: Finance, Tax, Trust; Informed: Support,
City Ops

• \*\*Change Order & Reschedule\*\* --- Responsible: Product;
Accountable: Product; Consulted: Support; Informed: Finance

• \*\*Deliverables & Acceptance\*\* --- Responsible: Product;
Accountable: Product; Consulted: Trust/Support; Informed: Finance

• \*\*Disputes\*\* --- Responsible: Support; Accountable: Trust;
Consulted: Legal/Product; Informed: Finance

• \*\*Payouts & Reserves\*\* --- Responsible: Payments/Finance;
Accountable: Finance; Consulted: Support; Informed: Trust

• \*\*Promotions (Boost/Featured)\*\* --- Responsible: Growth;
Accountable: Growth; Consulted: Product/Data/Trust; Informed: Support

• \*\*Verification (IDV/BG)\*\* --- Responsible: Trust; Accountable:
Trust; Consulted: Legal; Informed: Support

• \*\*Studios (Beta)\*\* --- Responsible: Studios PM; Accountable:
Product; Consulted: Trust/Legal; Informed: Support/City Ops

A3. Acronyms & Short Codes

S→I (Search→Inquiry) \| I→B (Inquiry→Booking) \| IDV (Identity
Verification) \| BG (Background Check) \| ER (Engagement Rate) \| ACH
(Automated Clearing House) \| KYC/KYB \| PCI \| WCAG \| RFP \| LBG \|
SOW \| PO

A4. Term/Label Canon (UI vs Data vs Legal)

We maintain a canonical mapping of UI labels, data field names, and
legal language to avoid drift. Example:\
UI: \'Change Order\' → Data: change_order_event → Legal: \'amendment\'.
UI: \'Buyer fee\' → Data: buyer_fee_amt → Legal: \'Service fee\'.

A5. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Product Ops. Review cadence: quarterly. Change control: PRD +
Slack #product‑ops; update Help Center and Admin copy on change.

Appendix B --- Data Dictionary (Quick Reference to §5.5)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose\
This appendix is a field‑level quick reference for analysts and
engineers. The authoritative schema lives in the warehouse (Section 5).
This guide summarizes Fact and Dimension tables, keys, privacy tags,
freshness, and common joins, so product and support can communicate
unambiguously.

B1. Naming, Keys & Privacy

Naming: snake_case for tables/columns. Facts store events/transactions;
Dimensions store entities/attributes.\
Keys: surrogate keys with id prefixes (user_id, booking_id). Foreign
keys explicit. Composite keys where necessary.\
Privacy tags: P0 (PII‑sensitive like TIN), P1 (contact), P2
(behavioral), P3 (public). Access controlled per §4.14.1.

B2. Core Dimensions

• \*\*user_dim\*\* --- User account and global settings.\
Fields: user_id (PK), created_at_ts, email_hash (P1), phone_hash (P1),
country_code, state_code, city, role_flags, idv_status,
trusted_pro_status, rep_overall_score, deletion_status

• \*\*service_profile_dim\*\* --- Role‑specific offerings.\
Fields: service_profile_id (PK), user_id (FK), role_type
(\'model\'\|\'photographer\'\|\'videographer\'\|\'creator\'), headline,
rate_min, rate_max, instant_book_enabled, nsfw_opt_in,
studio_verified_flag, rep_role_score

• \*\*location_dim\*\* --- Geo lookup.\
Fields: location_id (PK), city, state_code, lat, lng, metro_area,
timezone

• \*\*time_dim\*\* --- Calendar/time grain.\
Fields: time_id (PK), date, week, month, quarter, year, dow, hour

• \*\*studio_dim (beta)\*\* --- Studios/hosts.\
Fields: studio_id (PK), owner_user_id (FK), name, address_hash (P1),
verified_flag, deposit_default_amt, house_rules_version

B3. Core Facts (Events/Transactions)

• \*\*booking_fact\*\* --- One row per booking
request/acceptance/completion.\
Fields: booking_id (PK), buyer_user_id, provider_user_id,
service_profile_id, role_type, location_id, created_time_id, state
(\'requested\'\|\'accepted\'\|\'completed\'\|\'disputed\'\|\'canceled\'),
subtotal_amt, travel_fee_amt, buyer_fee_amt, provider_fee_amt, tax_amt,
payment_method (\'card\'\|\'ach\')

• \*\*booking_leg_fact (LBG)\*\* --- One row per leg (talent/studio) in
group bookings.\
Fields: leg_id (PK), booking_id (FK), leg_type (\'talent\'\|\'studio\'),
leg_subtotal_amt, leg_tax_amt, deposit_auth_amt, accept_time_id,
complete_time_id

• \*\*payment_fact\*\* --- Charges/refunds.\
Fields: payment_id (PK), booking_id, charge_amt, refund_amt, processor,
3ds_flag, ach_flag, status

• \*\*payout_fact\*\* --- Provider/host payouts.\
Fields: payout_id (PK), user_id, amount, reserve_withheld_amt,
reserve_released_amt, early_payout_fee_amt, status

• \*\*tax_quote_fact\*\* --- Tax engine responses.\
Fields: tax_quote_id (PK), booking_id, state_code, jurisdiction_code,
quote_amt, latency_ms, success_flag

• \*\*promotion_impression_fact\*\* --- Paid card impressions.\
Fields: impression_id (PK), service_profile_id, placement, qs_score,
bid_cpc, city, timestamp, buyer_session_id

• \*\*promotion_click_fact\*\* --- Clicks on promoted cards.\
Fields: click_id (PK), impression_id (FK), ctr_position,
valid_click_flag, cpc_charged_amt

• \*\*conversion_fact\*\* --- Inquiry/booking conversions attributed to
impressions.\
Fields: conversion_id (PK), booking_id, attributed_impression_id,
incrementality_cell, roas

• \*\*message_fact\*\* --- DM events.\
Fields: message_id (PK), thread_id, sender_user_id, receiver_user_id,
message_type, contains_link_flag, moderation_flag

• \*\*dispute_fact\*\* --- Dispute lifecycle.\
Fields: dispute_id (PK), booking_id, reason_code, evidence_items_count,
decision, time_to_decision_days

• \*\*moderation_fact\*\* --- Content moderation outcomes.\
Fields: moderation_id (PK), user_id, content_type, action, reason,
appeal_flag, final_decision

B4. Joins & Common Queries

Examples: profile discovery funnel; promotions ROAS; dispute loss rate;
payout latency by role. Include sample SQL patterns and caution about
double counting.

B5. Freshness & Quality SLOs

Gold tables freshness ≤ 15 min for events, ≤ 24h for aggregates. Data
quality gates: completeness, uniqueness, referential integrity.

B6. Ownership & Change Control

Owners: Data team. Schema changes require RFC; version notes; downstream
impact analysis.

Appendix C --- Policy Templates (SOW, Releases, House Rules, Adverse
Action)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose\
Provide neutral, plain‑English templates that users and staff can adopt.
These are not legal advice. They must be reviewed by counsel before
publication. Where FCRA applies (background checks), we include
pre‑adverse/adverse action letter templates and timing notes.

C1. SOW (Statement of Work) --- Template

Sections: Parties; Date/Location; Scope; Deliverables (manifest);
Usage/License; Fees/Deposits; Changes/Overtime; Travel; Cancellations;
Safety & Conduct; Confidentiality; Dispute Resolution; Signatures.\
Notes: Keep role‑agnostic; insert exhibit for role specifics (e.g.,
photo retouch counts, video cuts).

C2. Model Release --- Template

Plain‑English clauses: Consent; Scope of Use; Duration; Territory;
Compensation; Credit; Revocation limits; No moral rights; Safety; Age of
Majority declaration; Witness line. Includes fields to attach IDV
reference ID (not storing the ID itself in the document).

C3. Property/Studio Release --- Template

Clauses: Permission to use premises; Areas allowed; Time windows;
Restrictions (nudity policy compliance); Insurance; Indemnity; Damages;
Deposit rules; House rules; Signatures.

C4. House Rules (Studio) --- Template

Structure: Safety; Fire exits; No smoking/vaping; Sound limits; Maximum
occupancy; Cleanliness; Allowed props; Pet policy; Nudity policy;
Neighbor respect; Overtime fees; Deposit conditions; Contacts for
emergencies.

C5. FCRA Letters (Background Checks) --- Templates

Pre‑Adverse Action: Notice, copy of report, summary of rights, time to
respond (e.g., 5 business days).\
Adverse Action: Final decision, reasons, reporting agency contact,
rights to dispute, no decision by agency disclaimer.\
Timing notes: Timer starts when user receives the notice; admin console
tracks deadlines (see §4.14.3).

C6. Publishing & Versioning

Owner: Legal/Trust. Version control: numbered exhibits. City deltas:
callouts. Accessibility and plain‑language review required.

Appendix D --- City Scoring Model (Expansion Readiness)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose\
Provide an objective method to evaluate new cities for expansion,
avoiding hype‑driven decisions. The model aligns with Section 2 GTM and
Section 12 roadmap gates. It produces a composite score with go/no‑go
recommendations, data sources, and staffing implications.

D1. Scoring Axes & Weights (Example)

• \*\*Supply Depth (30%)\*\* --- Active creators/providers per 10k
population; studio partners; education partners; social presence.

• \*\*Demand Potential (25%)\*\* --- Local ad spend proxies; SMB
density; DTC presence; content‑hungry verticals.

• \*\*Unit Economics (20%)\*\* --- CPC expectations; estimated take‑rate
GMV; tax complexity; payment costs.

• \*\*Operational Readiness (15%)\*\* --- Moderator/Support
availability; local studio partners; legal comfort.

• \*\*Competitive/PR (10%)\*\* --- Competitor presence; partnership
opportunities; press friendliness.

D2. Data Sources & Collection

Internal: waitlists, signups, search traffic, conversion in adjacent
cities. External: census data, business registries, ad spend proxies,
social trend indices.

D3. Score Calculation & Thresholds

Normalize each axis to 0--100; apply weights; composite score ≥ 70 →
consider Beta; 60--69 → nurture; \< 60 → defer. Add qualitative notes.

D4. Decision Packet Template

One‑pager with score, map, supply heatmap, top partners, risks,
staffing, budget, PR plan, and a proposed launch window.

D5. Governance & Review

Quarterly review; Section 11 risk sanity check; Section 9 budget
alignment; Section 10 playbook readiness.

Appendix E --- Revenue Recognition Notes & Fee Math Examples (ties to
§3.1)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose\
Document how platform fees are recognized under a marketplace model, how
refunds and adjustments are treated, and provide clear numerical
examples that match receipts (§4.12) and fee engine rules (§3.1).
Coordinate with accounting counsel for GAAP compliance. This is not
accounting advice.

E1. Revenue Streams & When Recognized

Provider fee (commission) --- recognized at the point the service is
delivered and accepted (or auto‑accepted). Buyer service fee ---
recognized at transaction processing; refunded on provider‑fault
cancellations per policy. Promotions revenue --- recognized on delivery
of impressions/clicks or over the weekly term for Featured.

E2. Escrow, Refunds, Adjustments

Escrow liability sits until acceptance; change orders adjust the
contract value; refunds reduce recognized revenue if already recognized;
otherwise release liability.

E3. Worked Examples (Step‑by‑Step)

• \*\*Example A\*\* --- Talent booking \$600; buyer fee 5%; provider fee
12% minus Instant Book 1% and Trusted Pro 0.5%; ACH used; show journal
entries for charge, escrow, acceptance, payout, fees.

• \*\*Example B\*\* --- Change order +\$100; acceptance delayed; buyer
cancels under rules; compute partial refund and fee impact.

• \*\*Example C\*\* --- Dispute resulting in 30% refund post‑acceptance;
show revenue adjustment and payout clawback if applicable.

E4. Journal Entry Patterns (Illustrative)

Include debits/credits for cash, escrow liability, revenue (provider
fee, buyer fee), processor fees, promotions, refunds/chargebacks,
reserves, early payout fees.

E5. Reconciliation & Controls

Daily close checklist; settlement variances; dispute fees; promotions
credits; tax memos.

E6. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Finance. Review cadence: monthly with Section 9; sync with §4.12
ledger outputs and exports.

Appendix F --- Tax Nexus Matrix Snapshot (ties to §4.12/§5.10)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose\
Provide the structure of our tax nexus and taxability matrix without
hard‑coding rates or legal conclusions. This appendix explains how the
matrix is maintained, how the tax engine allowlist works, and how
Support communicates tax outcomes. It is a guide, not legal advice.

F1. Matrix Structure (Template)

Columns: State; City/County; Taxability of services (talent, studio,
digital deliverables); Marketplace facilitator obligations; Sourcing
rule (origin/destination); Registration status; Effective date;
Notes/links. Values are maintained in Admin by Tax role and published to
the tax engine allowlist.

F2. Change Control & Reviews

Quarterly review with counsel; engine sync logs; reconciliation
variances trigger investigation; audit trail stored in Admin (§4.14.7).

F3. Support Macros & Receipts Language

Plain‑English explainer for buyers: when and why taxes appear; ACH
discount messaging; amended receipt process for state‑level changes.

F4. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Tax & Compliance. Acceptance: zero reconciliation variances
beyond tolerance; clear help‑center entries; training complete.

Appendix G --- Experiment Pre‑Registration Template (ties to §5.13)

Generated on 2025-11-04 23:53:44 UTC

Purpose\
Create a repeatable, auditable template for experiments that affect
discovery, pricing, messaging limits, or safety thresholds.
Pre‑registration reduces bias (\'p‑hacking\') and aligns teams on
guardrails and success criteria before launch.

G1. Template Fields

• \*\*Title & ID\*\* --- Experiment name and tracking ID.

• \*\*Owner & Reviewers\*\* --- Product, Data, Trust, Finance sign‑offs.

• \*\*Hypothesis\*\* --- Falsifiable statement including target segment
and expected direction of effect.

• \*\*Primary Metrics\*\* --- Exactly one or two (e.g., S→I, I→B,
dispute loss rate). Defined in §5 catalog.

• \*\*Guardrail Metrics\*\* --- Must not degrade (e.g., organic S→I,
buyer hide rate, safety reports, payout latency).

• \*\*Population & Randomization\*\* --- Eligibility, stratification
(city/role), unit of assignment, holdout size.

• \*\*Sample Size & Power\*\* --- Pre‑computed; expected duration with
traffic estimates.

• \*\*Treatments\*\* --- What changes and what remains constant;
screenshots/copy.

• \*\*Instrumentation\*\* --- Events, experiment bucketing, attribution
windows.

• \*\*Analysis Plan\*\* --- Statistical tests, treatment of outliers,
sequential monitoring rules.

• \*\*Stop/Extend/End Criteria\*\* --- Numerical thresholds; min
runtime; quality checks.

• \*\*Rollout Plan\*\* --- Flags, cities, staged ramp, rollback recipe.

• \*\*Comms Plan\*\* --- Internal release notes; help‑center changes;
external messaging if any.

• \*\*Risks & Ethics\*\* --- Identify bias risks, fairness, and user
harm; mitigation.

• \*\*Post‑Mortem Checklist\*\* --- What worked, what didn't, what to
productize.

G2. Example (Promotions Density Cap A/B)

Outline a worked example with metrics (ROAS ≥ 2.5×) and guardrails
(organic S→I no worse than −3%). Include holdout cell and city gating.

G3. Storage & Discoverability

All pre‑regs stored in the warehouse (Gold) and mirrored in the Admin
experiments registry; searchable by owner, city, and metric.

G4. Acceptance & Ownership

Owner: Data Science. Acceptance: no experiment ships without a pre‑reg;
post‑mortems added within 7 days of completion.
